    Download Hi-Res ImageDownload to MS-PowerPointCite This:J. Phys. Chem. C 2020, 124, 5, 2817-2836
    ADVERTISEMENT
    RETURN TO ISSUEPREVArticleNEXT

    First-Principles Approach for Assessing Cold Electron Injection Efficiency of Dye-Sensitized Solar Cell: Elucidation of Mechanism of Charge Injection and Recombination

    • Pabitra Narayan Samanta*
      Pabitra Narayan Samanta
      Interdisciplinary Center for Nanotoxicity, Department of Chemistry, Physics and Atmospheric Sciences, Jackson State University, Jackson, Mississippi 39217, United States
      *E-mail: pabitra.samanta@icnanotox.org (P.N.S.).
      More by Pabitra Narayan Samanta
      • , 
    • D. Majumdar*
      D. Majumdar
      Interdisciplinary Center for Nanotoxicity, Department of Chemistry, Physics and Atmospheric Sciences, Jackson State University, Jackson, Mississippi 39217, United States
      *E-mail: devashis@icnanotox.org (D.M.).
      More by D. Majumdar
      • , 
    • Szczepan Roszak
      Szczepan Roszak
      Advanced Materials Engineering and Modelling Group, Faculty of Chemistry, Wroclaw University of Science and Technology, Wyb. Wyspianskiego 27, 50-370 Wroclaw, Poland
      More by Szczepan Roszak
      • , and 
    • Jerzy Leszczynski*
      Jerzy Leszczynski
      Interdisciplinary Center for Nanotoxicity, Department of Chemistry, Physics and Atmospheric Sciences, Jackson State University, Jackson, Mississippi 39217, United States
      *E-mail: jerzy@icnanotox.org (J.L.).
      More by Jerzy Leszczynski
      http://orcid.org/0000-0001-5290-6136
    Cite this: J. Phys. Chem. C 2020, 124, 5, 2817–2836

    SUBJECTS:

    Get e-Alerts

    Abstract

    The adequacy of the inclusion of spacer units in the metal-free D−π–A organic dyes concerning the augmentation of dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) efficiency has been examined through the excited-state simulations of the charge injection and recombination processes at the dye–semiconductor interface. Within the framework of the time-dependent density functional theory, the proposed computational studies focus on the precise evaluation of pivotal factors controlling the rates of photoinduced charge-transfer and energy-transfer processes, including electronic coupling, reorganization energy, and threshold energy barrier in the semiclassical Marcus formalism. The estimation of the fluorescent state appears to be the crucial step while explaining the ultrafast electron injection process and the charge recombination at the Marcus inverted region, as revealed by the obtained results. The retardation of charge recombination is facilitated by the insertion of a thiophene moiety between the π-bridge and the acceptor units. The estimated cold electron injection efficiencies deploying the Onsager–Braun theory, which rely on the computations of cold electron injection lifetime and cold electron lifetime, show a linear correlation with the experimental photovoltaic parameters of the DSSC comprising short-circuit current density, open-circuit voltage, and power conversion efficiency. The outcomes of the present investigation establish a basis for unraveling the mechanism of intricate dynamical processes upon photoexcitation of the sensitizers, as well as devising plausible routes for functional DSSC materials.

    1. Introduction

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) are one of the most studied solar-energy-based devices along with various other organic-material-based solar cells. (1−4) These devices are deemed to limit the use of fossil energy resources in a more cost-effective way, although the proper efficiency is yet to be achieved. Since the seminal work on dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) sprouted by O’Regan and Grätzel in 1991, efforts are being paid in developing functional DSSC materials through the multitude of experimental and theoretical studies. With the aim of improving the photovoltaic performance of the DSSC, numerous experiments have been conducted to assess the impact of structural modification of the synthesized photoluminescent dyes on the intrinsic photophysical parameters of the solar cell such as short-circuit current density (Jsc) and open-circuit voltage (Voc). (2,3) For a detailed understanding of the underlying photophysical mechanisms of charge-transfer and recombination processes, the advances in theoretical approaches have been emerged. The present computational study is directed toward the evaluation of intricate electronic factors affecting the Jsc and Voc of the DSSC, as well as the exploration of the quantum transport behavior of quasi-particles through the estimations of rate constants of the elementary processes.
    A typical DSSC device is composed of a semiconductor (typically TiO2 thin film), a photosensitizer (dyes), and an electrolyte containing I– and I3– ions, a counter electrode (e.g., Pt), and a transparent conducting substrate. The working process of such a solar cell could be systematically described through the following steps (2,3)(A1)(A2)(A3)(A4)The first step is the excitation of the dye molecule through the absorption of light in the visible–near-IR range (eq A1). The electronically excited dye injects electrons in the conduction band of TiO2 (eq A2), and this is followed by the regeneration of the oxidized dye (dye+) by a reducing agent of the electrolyte (I–) through the formation of I3– (eq A3). Reduction of I3– through the interaction with the counter electrode (Pt) regenerates I– (eq A4), and the overall charge carrier motion gives rise to the macroscopic photocurrent. The electronic density increases in the oxide as a result of the photoinduced electron transfer from the dye to the semiconductor. It gives rise to an electrochemical potential difference (i.e., a voltage) between the semiconductor and the electrolyte. (2,3) This mechanism shows that the sensitizer dyes play a significant role in capturing solar energy and propagating electron transfer in the cell.
    The solar-energy-to-electricity conversion efficiency of a DSSC is discerned by the combined effects of several factors viz. the short-circuit current density (Jsc), the open-circuit voltage (Voc), the fill factor (FF) of the cell, and the intensity of the incident light (Pin). Analytically, η could be expressed as (3)(1.1)The photocurrent density is crucially governed by the charge generation and collection efficiency, which, in turn, rely on the light-harvesting efficiency (LHE) of the dye, the kinetics of electron injection, dye regeneration, and charge transport within the cell (as discussed in eqs A2–A4).
    The quest for a superior dye sensitizer with integrated light-harvesting efficiency has led to the recognition of diverse organic chromophores including transition-metal-based dyes, (2,5−8) especially ruthenium-incorporated dyes, zinc porphyrins, (9−11) and metal-free organic dyes. However, the practical implementations of ruthenium- and porphyrin-based dyes are categorically hindered by their scarce resources, difficulty in the synthetic process, as well as environmental concerns. The metal-free organic dyes could be considered as the donor (D)–acceptor (A)-based systems involving π-spacer units in between. Depending on the orientations of π-bridges between D and A moieties, the metal-free organic dyes could be classified as D−π–A, (12,13) D–A−π–A, (14−26) and A−π–D−π–A. (27) From the viewpoints of the facile synthetic approach, the ease of structural modification with tunable optical properties, affordable price, and minimal environmental risks, the metal-free organic dyes have been exposed to be advantageous for photovoltaic applications. (28−31) Although these dyes are yet to outperform the efficiencies of transition-metal-based sensitizers, the evidence is there that the performance of such metal-free sensitizers could be raised further in combination with some redox shuttle (like Co(II/III)). (32,33)
    The design of effective DSSC sensitizers essentially demands the discretion of a multitude of optoelectronic features such as band alignment, transition characters of optical absorption spectra, and solid-state properties including dye aggregation, morphology, and mode of assembly on the TiO2 photoanode. A number of experimental studies have been performed to elucidate how the electron–hole separation and recombination processes at the semiconductor–dye interface depend on intriguing factors including molecular geometry, anchoring groups, bridge lengths, surface orientation, defects, as well as ion concentration to mitigate the detrimental aspects related to sluggish power conversion efficiency and restricted long-term stability, as revealed by the organic dye-based DSSCs. With the advent of computer technologies, numerous density functional theory (DFT)-based theoretical studies (34−51) have been carried out to understand the absorption characteristics of the DSSC dyes in both free and adsorbed states (mostly on TiO2), the factors responsible for charge mobilization procedures in the complex systems, and their consequences on the efficiency of the photovoltaic device. Although these in silico approaches have explained some prime issues for improving DSSC performance, the detailed microscopic mechanism of complex charge transport process at the interface together with the identification of entangled parameters ensuring the stability of photoexcited dye sensitizers is still obscured. For instance, the quantum efficiency of the charge separation strait simultaneously depends on the kinetics of electron injection to the TiO2, and all of the probable pathways for the deactivation of the excited dye concerning luminescence, thermal relaxation, and electron transfer to the acceptor moiety in solution or on the interface.
    In this context, the present theoretical investigation aims to comprehend the driving forces of electron injection and electron–hole recombination processes for the metal-free organic dyes using state-of-the-art first-principles-based approaches within the framework of time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT). We have selected five recently synthesized DSSC photosensitizers, (52,53) which are proposed to exhibit higher short-circuit current densities and power conversion efficiencies compared to earlier metal-free organic dyes using I–/I3– as redox shuttle. These D−π–A dyes comprise triphenylamine (TPA) as the D unit, cyanoacrylic acid (CAA) as the A unit, and highly planar tetrathienoacene (TTA) core as the π-bridge unit. The TTA core of these dyes contains a long alkyl substituent (R = n-C15H31) to suppress dye aggregation and charge recombination on the TiO2 surface. All of these dyes contain thiophene (T) as the spacer unit between the π-bridge and the D/A units so that the orientation effect of thiophene on the performance of DSSC could be monitored. The objectives of the projected research also focus on examining a variety of factors impinging Jsc and Voc of the solar cell device through the critical assessment of charge-transfer bands, as well as the optical and electrochemical properties of photoexcited dyes as a function of the dye’s building block. The determination of the nature of the fluorescent state of the dye sensitizers is one of the foremost tasks because the stability of this state (in terms of a lifetime) endows a significant role in the electron mobilization process in the cell. This parameter further controls the electron coupling strength between the donor and acceptor parts of the dye and could be expressed in terms of electron-hopping and hole-hopping rates and their lifetimes. By employing the Marcus electron-transfer theory, the crux of the research objectives is directed toward the estimation of rate constants for electron-transfer processes from a specified state of the photosensitizer to the acceptor states of the semiconductor together with the recognition of the effectiveness of π-spacer units to the escalation of electron injection efficiency. The electron- and hole-hopping mechanisms have been critically analyzed through the estimations of the electronic coupling between the dye’s excited state and the conduction band of the semiconductor, employing different computational strategies such as the generalized Mulliken–Hush (GMH) method, (54) the Förster–Dexter formalism, (55,56) and the semiclassical Marcus theory. (57) The time scales for electron injection between the dye and the TiO2 surface are further computed by accounting the effect of adsorption on the relative alignment of electronic states of the photosensitizers and the lifetime broadening using the Newns–Anderson model. (58)

    2. Computational Details

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    Ab initio-based DFT calculations have been performed to unveil the ground-state electronic structures and properties of structurally diverse metal-free organic DSSC sensitizers by employing the B3LYP hybrid functional (59−61) and 6-31G(d) basis sets for all of the atoms involved. During the structural relaxation of molecular assemblies smeared with the donor−π–bridge–acceptor (D−π–A) framework, no constraint was imposed and the SCF convergence criteria were adjusted to 10–6 au on both energy and density. All of the stationary points on the potential energy surface were ascertained from the harmonic vibrational frequency analysis using the ideal gas approximation.
    To unravel the impact of amalgamation of various π-conjugated spacer units on the charge-transfer excitation properties of linear and branched alkyl-substituted TTAR-based chromophores, optical transitions of all of the DSSC sensitizers are studied by conducting TD-DFT computations. To simulate the UV–vis absorption spectra, the vertical singlet excitation energies and oscillator strengths are estimated at their ground-state optimized geometries for a maximum of 50 dipole and spin-allowed excited states. However, the accurate prediction of vertical excitation energies of the low-lying charge-transfer transitions within the formalism of the conventional TD-DFT method is a formidable task. To alleviate this problem, we have assessed the efficiency and robustness of various hybrid and meta-hybrid functionals such as B3LYP, CAM-B3LYP, (62) M06-2X, (63) and ωB97XD (64) in conjunction with the 6-31G(d) basis sets for simulating the electronic absorption spectra. The CAM-B3LYP functional corresponds to a long-range corrected version of the hybrid B3LYP functional employing the Coulomb attenuating method. The M06-2X functional is a parameterized semiempirical hybrid functional with a double amount of nonlocal exchange energy. On the other hand, ωB97XD refers to a modified B97 exchange–correlation (XC) functional and incorporates the long-range correction deploying the atom–atom dispersion. Figure S1 (Supporting Information) elucidates the variation of the computed excited electronic states of the selective organic dye D5 with the alteration of XC functionals. The long-range corrected band gaps are found to be considerably larger compared to the B3LYP-derived values. The largest gaps are obtained when the ωB97XD functional is employed. This is mainly due to the inclusion of the full Hartree–Fock exchange term in the ωB97XD functional at long distances. The maximum absorption wavelength (λmax) using the CAM-B3LYP functional is estimated to be about 452 nm, which corroborates well with the previously reported experimental value of 485 nm. (53) The difference lies within the threshold limit, 0.15 eV, when the simulated and experimental spectra are compared. However, the computed excited-state transition energies using the B3LYP hybrid functional are overestimated compared to the CAM-B3LYP and other long-range corrected XC functionals. This is because the former functional is not asymptotically correct to describe the charge-transfer states. Thus, by examining the electronic excitation energies and UV–vis spectra, the CAM-B3LYP is considered to be a dependable and efficient XC functional in predicting optoelectronic properties of TPA-TTAR-CAA-containing molecular dyes. To mimic the optical absorption spectra measured in the 1,2-dichlorobenzene (o-DCB) solution, (52,53) solvent effects were included through the conductor-like polarizable continuum model (CPCM) within the self-consistent reaction field (SCRF) approach. (65,66)
    For the estimation of fluorescence lifetime, the linear response (LR) TD-CAM-B3LYP calculations using the CPCM method are carried out to optimize the excited-state geometries and compute vertical emission energies. In an earlier study, the competence of LR formalism in conjunction with the PCM method for determining excited-state geometries and emission maxima of D−π–A-based DSSC sensitizers has been demonstrated by Bernini et al. (67) In that study, the predicted vertical emission energies within the LR-PCM/TD-DFT framework employing the range-separated hybrid functional, especially CAM-B3LYP and ωB97XD, were found to correlate well with the experimental data. Since the time scale of an emission process is much faster than that of the solvent dynamics, we have also employed the state-specific (SS) approach (68,69) to account for the dynamical solvent effect and to perform corrections on the vertical emission energies. For a meticulous consideration of the solvent effect on an emission process, the ground-state electronic energies are computed with the nonequilibrium solvation. Within the SS scheme, the electronic density of the emitting excited state is used to calculate the ground-state energy. The emission energy within the SS approach (ΔEemiSS) is computed by(2.1)where EEQES (Q0ES) refers to the energy of the excited state (ES) with equilibrium solvation at the optimized excited-state geometry (Q0ES) of the photosensitizer, and ENEQGS (Q0ES) defines the energy of the ground state (GS) with nonequilibrium solvation at Q0ES.
    For a deeper understanding of the electron injection process at the dye–semiconductor interface, each DSSC photosensitizer is further allowed to interact with the TiO2 surface. To emulate the photophysical properties of the DSSC dyes adsorbed on TiO2 thin film, the optimized D−π–A organic dyes are anchored on a (TiO2)9 cluster model, which was derived from the anatase (101) surface, in a monodentate adsorption mode where the carboxylic −OH group of the CAA moiety interacts with a surface oxygen atom through the hydrogen bonding. In an earlier study, the adequacy of small (TiO2)n nanoclusters in reproducing the crucial features of absorption spectra such as the energy shift of the main band upon the binding of dye on the TiO2 surface has been demonstrated by Sánchez-de-Armas et al. (70) In that study, a unit of (TiO2)6 as the smallest nanocluster model was identified to be suitable for describing the electronic structure of the dye–TiO2 system, as well as accounting the qualitative features of the spectra within the framework of LR TD-DFT. In another study, the (TiO2)9 cluster is demonstrated to be large enough to simulate the electronic absorption spectra and comprehend the electron injection mechanism. (71) Later, Li et al. (23) have successfully employed the (TiO2)9 cluster model to simulate the electronic absorption spectra of D–A−π–A-based dyes supported on the TiO2 surface and determine the charge-transfer characteristics of DSSC. Moreover, to validate the cluster model used in the present study, the computed structural, electronic, and spectral properties such as dihedral angle, highest occupied molecular orbital–lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (HOMO–LUMO) energy gaps, and absorption and emission maxima of the dye–TiO2 complexes are compared with those of earlier experimental results. The molecular geometries of the dye–(TiO2)9 composites are then relaxed by performing DFT calculations using the B3LYP hybrid functional and 6-31G(d) basis sets for all of the constituent atoms except Ti atoms. We have used the LANL2DZ basis set, as well as the effective core potential (ECP) for the Ti atoms. The adsorption strength between the dye and the TiO2 surface is estimated within the supermolecular approach using the following expression(2.2)where Edye and ETiO2 are the total energies of the isolated dye and (TiO2)9 cluster, respectively. Edye+TiO2 refers to the total energy of the dye–(TiO2)9 complex. All of the DFT- and TD-DFT-based computations have been performed using the Gaussian 16 suite of program. (72)
    The nature of molecule–surface interaction is further characterized from the projected density of state (PDOS) spectra, electrostatic potential (ESP) maps, and localized orbital locator (LOL) analyses. (73) The natural bond orbital (NBO) charge analysis of the electron population on each atom center was performed for each dye–TiO2 complex.
    On the basis of the relaxed ground-state structures, LR TD-DFT calculations were carried out to simulate the optical absorption spectra of the dye–TiO2 composite in the o-DCB solvent employing the CPCM solvation model and CAM-B3LYP functional. For each complex, the vertical excitation energies and oscillator strengths are evaluated for the lowest 50 dipole and spin-allowed excited states. The impact of different asymmetric π-bridges on the fluorescence lifetimes of the dyes adsorbed on the TiO2 surface is subsequently estimated through the computations of vertical emission energies from the relaxed excited-state geometry within the LR- and SS-TD-CAM-B3LYP/CPCM formalisms. The predicted photophysical properties are compared with the experimental data acquired from the femtosecond time-resolved photoluminescence (FTR-PL) measurements to assess the competency of the dye–TiO2 cluster model in reproducing the photoexcited electron dynamics. The photoinduced charge-transfer excited states are further assessed based on the computed values of the charge-transfer distance, the amount of charge transferred, and the associated charge-transfer dipole moments for the low-lying excited states. (74) The electron densities of the ground and excited states obtained with TD-DFT using the CAM-B3LYP functional are deployed to determine the barycenter of the density depletion and increment regions associated with the electronic transition and compute the charge transferred through the integral of the density depletion function over all space. The effectiveness of TTAR-based D−π–A dyes toward the exciton dissociation at the dye–semiconductor interface is quantified through the estimations of the exciton binding energy that can be regarded as the electrostatic Coulomb interaction between the particle and hole densities. (75,76)

    3. Results and Discussion

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The effectiveness of various symmetric and asymmetric π-spacer units toward the escalation of DSSC efficiency is assessed through the exploration of ground-state and excited-state molecular geometries on the potential energy hypersurface. Different electrochemical and photophysical properties are subsequently evaluated within the framework of TD-DFT computations to unravel the charge injection and recombination processes at the dye–semiconductor interface. The efficiencies of photoinduced charge-transfer processes are ascertained by analyzing interfacial electronic coupling and injection rates for radiative and nonradiative decays of excited states of the organic photosensitizers. The estimated optical responses of the alkyl-substituted TTAR-based DSSC sensitizers in combination with the recognition of crucial factors influencing the photovoltaic properties of the solar cell are discussed in the following subsections.

    3.1. Structures and Electronic Properties of the Dyes and Dye/TiO2 Composites

    The schematic representations of all of the considered isolated dyes are displayed in Figure 1. The computed dihedral angles for each DSSC sensitizer at the B3LYP/6-31G(d) level of theory are provided in Table S1 (Supporting Information). The D part (TPA) of these dyes has a propeller-like nonplanar structure, while the A part (CAA) exhibits a planar geometry. The π-bridges are not in the same plane with the TPA unit, albeit the CAA unit is almost conjugated with the π-bridges, as evident from the predicted dihedral angles and the connecting bond lengths between the D and A moieties. The TPA unit is on the average 40° out of plane, while the acceptor unit always shows an angular deviation within 2–2.5° with respect to the various π-bridges of the dye molecules. The dyes D1–D4 comprise a linear alkyl chain (R = n-C15H31), while the fifth dye, D5, has a somewhat smaller branched alkyl chain (R = b-C8H17). Fully optimized structures of these dyes show that these chains remain vertically above and below the TTA core with a fully staggered conformation of the alkyl units. These chains were not considered in the earlier calculations (52) and were replaced by the −CH3 groups with the assumption that the alkyl chain length does not affect the basic electronic properties of these dyes in their ground states. It will be observed subsequently that this assumption is not illogical, although due to the long alkyl chain effect, the absorption spectra of the dyes show a somewhat blue shift with respect to the previously computed values.
    The molecular geometries of the dye–semiconductor composites are subsequently explored to simulate the interfacial charge injection process, as declared in the reaction step (A2) of DSSC. The ground-state optimized geometries of the hybrid composites obtained after the adsorption of photosensitizers (D1–D5) onto the surface of the finite (TiO2)9 cluster are represented in Figure S2. The geometric features of the optimized structures show that the dyes stay vertically above the TiO2 cluster surface anchored through the HO–C═O part of the acceptor moiety with a Ti-atom. The computed O–Ti–O angle (θ1) of all of these dye–TiO2 complexes lies in the range of 84–96°. The dihedral angle (θ2) defining the inclination of dyes with respect to the semiconductor surface was found to vary between ∼1 and 3° in all of the dye/(TiO2)9 complexes, indicating a cis-orientation of the contact angle. The computed closest distance (R) between the TiO2 nanocage and the anchoring group of the DSSC sensitizer is presented in Table 1. The interacting distance between the carbonyl oxygen of the CAA unit of the dye and the Ti-atom is predicted to be longer than the normal Ti–O bond length (∼2.0 Å). Moreover, a relatively strong hydrogen-bonding interaction mediated through the carboxyl hydrogen atom of the CAA moiety and the oxygen atom of the TiO2 surface is established for each dye–semiconductor composite. The robust interaction between the photosensitizers and the semiconductor surface is further substantiated by the estimated adsorption energies lying in the range of −1.93 to −2.96 eV (Table 1).
    Table 1. Computed Optimized Ti–O Distances (R) between the Binding Site of TiO2 Cluster and the Closest Atom of the Cyanoacrylic Acid Group of Each Dye, Adsorption Energies (Eads), Total Dipole Moment (D), and Shift in the Conduction Band Energy (ΔECB) of TiO2 and Dye for the Adsorption of DSSC Sensitizer on the Surface of (TiO2)9 Cluster
    dyeR (Å)Eads (eV)D (D)ΔECB,TiO2 (eV)ΔECB,dye (eV)Voc (exp)a (V)
    D11.97–2.7328.360.561.050.946
    D21.95–2.9625.830.561.000.893
    D32.06–1.9425.890.590.810.833
    D42.06–1.9326.130.580.760.832
    D51.97–2.5927.030.520.980.810
    a

    Refs (52,53).

    Next, to unveil the nature of the interaction between the dye and the TiO2 cluster, we place an emphasis on the probing of the electrostatic and charge-transfer effects arising at the interface. The changes in the electrostatic charge density distributions are illustrated through the simulated isosurface maps of the electrostatic potential (ESP) for the isolated D3 dye and the D3–TiO2 composite in Figure 2a,b. The red regions on the ESP map signify the accumulation of electronic charges, while the blue patches develop for the charge depletion. Due to the high electronegativity of oxygen compared to that of carbon, the presence of the carboxyl group at the acceptor unit allows more electron-sufficient sites, which, in turn, promote intermolecular interactions with the positive centers, as well as hydrogen bond interactions with the polar substrates.
    Since the TiO2 surface acts as an electron acceptor, the dye–surface interaction is facilitated by the negatively charged site of the DSSC sensitizer. The comparison of ESP maps manifests that the distribution of the electrostatic potential is significantly perturbed by the adsorption of dye on the surface of the TiO2 nanocage. The occurrence of the substantial charge rearrangement is further exemplified through the shaded surface map with the projection of the localized orbital locator (LOL) at the plane of conjugation (Figure 2c).
    The formation of a dye–semiconductor bond is supported by the appearance of charge accumulation and depletion lobes around the Ti-atom of the semiconductor and the O-atom of the carbonyl of the CAA unit, respectively. Similar density distribution pictures, comparing the ESP and LOL maps, are depicted in Figures S3 and S4, and they point to the interaction features close to the D3–TiO2 complex. These structural features are also comparable to the previously studied situations of the isonicotinic acid interactions on the (101) TiO2 cluster surface. (77)
    Although the experimentally measured values of adsorption energies for the dye–TiO2 complexes are obscured, the subtle interplay between the electronic structure of dye–semiconductor assemblies and the binding strength could be rationalized from the data obtained by X-ray reflectivity (XRR) and optical spectroscopic measurements. The experimental dye-loading values estimated by the optical spectrophotometry are 2.1, 1.3, 7.4, and 6.6 (×10–8 mol/mg) for the dyes D1, D2, D3, and D4, respectively. (52) These loading values correspond to the tilt angles of these dyes with respect to the TiO2 cluster surface. The lower the dye-loading value, the higher are the tilt angles. The computed tilt angle order from XRR measurements is D2 (∼74°) > D1 (∼70°) > D4 (∼58°) > D3 (∼48°). (52) The dye-loading value of D5 was not reported, but the tilt angle from XRR measurements is ∼60°. (53) Thus, it could be assumed that the dye-loading value of D5 is less than that of D4 but greater than that of D1. We did not exactly compute the tilt angles of dye–(TiO2)9 complexes for their optimized structures, but the angle θ1, as discussed above, could be assumed to be proportional to the tilt angles of these dyes with respect to the (TiO2)9 surface. The computed θ1 follows the order D2 > D1 > D5 > D4 ≈ D3 (Figure S2). This order closely resembles the XRR-data trend. Moreover, the lower dye-loading value is related to the higher adsorption efficiency of the dyes. Since the adsorption efficiency is directly proportional to the Eads of the dyes, the computed values of Eads in Table 1 vindicate the experimental trend of the dye-loading values (and the observed order of the tilt angles as well).
    Afterward, the effectiveness of the moderation of π-spacer units on the electrochemical performance of DSSC has been assessed by analyzing the alignment of electronic energy levels, as well as the density distributions of frontier molecular orbitals (MOs). The relative orientations of the computed MO eigenvalues corresponding to the HOMO and LUMO of pristine photosensitizer and dye–semiconductor complexes are portrayed in Figure 3. The calculated HOMO energies of the respective dyes are found to correlate well with those obtained by the cyclic voltammetry (CV) measurements. (52,53) The predicted trend in the HOMO–LUMO energy gap due to the insertion of a thiophene spacer unit is in accordance with the experimental results. The abilities of the electron injection and regeneration of the oxidized dyes are substantiated by the predicted higher LUMO energy levels compared to those of the conduction band edge of TiO2 and the lower HOMO energy levels relative to the redox potential of (I–/I3–), respectively. In the case of dye/TiO2 composites, both the HOMO and LUMO energy levels are shifted toward lower energies, and the gap is also diminished. Except for D3–TiO2, the reduction in the HOMO–LUMO energy gap for the adsorption of DSSC dyes on the TiO2 surface follows the same trend as observed in the isolated dyes. The calculated isosurfaces of the electron density distribution of frontier MOs are depicted in Figure S5 to visualize the impact of binding pathways of π-spacer units on the electron delocalization of the TTAR-based D−π–A dyes. It reveals that the LUMO orbitals are distributed on the acceptor moiety and the part of the π-bridge, while the HOMO orbitals are on the donor moiety, as well as the part of the TTAR unit adjacent to it. The extent of electron density distributions of frontier MOs at the π-bridge is indicative of the effectual intramolecular charge transfer from D to A units of the dyes through the π-spacer.
    Although the HOMO energies of all of the dyes are lower than the valence band of TiO2 (−4.0 eV), this is not necessarily the driving force for the hole transfer mechanism. The difference of Fermi levels, i.e., the free energy of the hole in the two materials, is the actual driving force. Thus, it is important to go beyond the HOMO–LUMO energy level analysis and investigate the detailed photophysical behavior of the dyes, as well as the dye/(TiO2)9 composite systems for any reasonable discussion of DSSC.

    3.2. Absorption and Emission Spectra of the Dyes

    The characteristics of electronic transitions corresponding to the low-lying excited states have been explored within the TD-DFT framework for elucidating the influence of thiophene units in conjunction with the linear and branched alkyl-substituted TTAR-based π-bridges on the light-harvesting abilities of photosensitizers. The simulated absorption spectra of the dyes D1–D5 are delineated in Figure 4a. The calculated vertical excitation energies (Eex), oscillator strengths (f), dipole strengths (|rk,k′|2), and major contributions of the MOs for the electronic excitations (f > 0.1) are reported in Table S2. The experimental Eex is also presented in the table for comparison. The simulated molar extinction coefficients at the CAM-B3LYP/6-31g(d) level of theory and the estimated values of the maximum absorption wavelength (λmax) for each DSSC sensitizer agree well with the experimental data. This is quite expected, as it would be shown later that the excited states of these dyes have charge separation and the CAM-B3LYP technique is appropriate to model such cases.
    Next, the nature of several intense peaks appeared in the visible and near-UV regions of the absorption band is resolved through the isosurface plots of the electron–hole density distribution. The electron–hole distributions reveal that there is charge separation in most of these excited states, and the higher excited states S4 (D1), S4 (D2), S3 (D3), S3 (D4), S3 (D5) of these dyes are the charge-transfer states, as illustrated in Figure 4b,c for the S1 and S3 states of the D3 dye and Figure S6 in the Supporting Information for the rest of the dyes.
    The key parameters including Δr index (measure of the average hole–electron distance upon photoexcitation), S (extent of overlap between hole–electron centroids), DCT (distance between the centroids of the hole and electron), μnorm (dipole moment of a state with respect to the ground state), and Ec (attractive hole–electron Coulomb energy) of a particular state have been considered to quantify the extent of charge-transfer process upon photoexcitation. Table 2 displays the magnitude of such parameters. The μnorm values in Table 2 indicate that the real charge-transfer state lies above the S1 state of the dyes. Although the charge-transfer states could be clearly specified for the dyes, the S1 state also has appreciable μnorm values, suggesting that they are charge-separated species. The obtained results comply with the isosurface maps of the electron–hole distribution (Figures 4b,c and S6).
    Table 2. Computed Δr Index, Overlapping Extent of the Hole and Electron (S), Distance between the Centroid of the Hole and Electron (DCT), Variation of Dipole Moment with Respect to the Ground State (μnorm), and Hole–Electron Coulomb Attractive Energy (EC) for the Low-Lying Excited States of Each DSSC Sensitizer
    dyetransitionΔr (Å)SDCT (Å)μnorm (au)EC (eV)
    D1S0 → S17.640.472.404.53–3.25
     S0 → S34.190.342.144.03–3.86
     S0 → S45.350.445.269.94–2.42
    D2S0 → S16.860.530.300.56–2.69
     S0 → S24.730.503.606.77–2.35
     S0 → S33.280.361.021.95–3.09
     S0 → S45.340.269.7418.30–1.56
     S0 → S54.350.504.348.17–2.11
    D3S0 → S17.370.531.773.36–2.92
     S0 → S25.030.523.586.76–2.24
     S0 → S36.100.437.5614.28–1.92
     S0 → S45.050.492.665.04–2.62
     S0 → S54.510.544.368.24–2.19
    D4S0 → S111.230.492.624.98–2.76
     S0 → S26.950.551.983.75–2.14
     S0 → S311.190.2911.5121.84–1.43
     S0 → S45.250.552.224.22–1.98
     S0 → S56.110.352.965.60–3.14
    D5S0 → S110.000.462.705.11–3.75
     S0 → S26.760.542.825.34–2.96
     S0 → S39.160.339.7018.34–2.20
     S0 → S46.300.363.426.49–3.41
     S0 → S55.400.522.815.32–2.74
    The parameters Δr and DCT are also estimated to investigate the intrinsic characteristics of electronic excitations for the DSSC sensitizers. The larger values of Δr and DCT imply the higher possibility of electron transfer. The predicted large values of DCT for the CT states of each dye are accompanied by the miniature of the extent of overlap between the hole and electron centroids (S values). The electronic states of all of these dyes are maintaining these intermolecular charge-transfer (ICT) criteria except the S1 state of D2. Here, the low DCT (0.30 Å) and μnorm (0.56 au) and high overlap values (S: 0.53) indicate its local excitation (LE) character. The Δr value (6.86 Å) in this case is contradictory, although it has been previously shown that the Δr index is not always correct to explain the ICT mechanism. (70)
    The depiction of isosurface maps of the hole and electron centroids for the dyes D1 and D2 (Figure 4d,e) reflects the nature of the excitation of these dyes. The position of the hole- and electron-centroid regions reveals the LE character of the S1 state of D2. The computed Ec values in Table 2 are also used as an index to judge the excitation nature of these vertical excited states. It is usually defined as (76)(3.2.1)where e and ε0 are, respectively, the elementary charge and vacuum permittivity. The ρ terms correspond to the densities of the natural transition orbitals (NTOs) of the hole (ρh) and electron (ρe) with coordinates r⃗1 and r⃗2. The high Ec values in Table 2 (also called exciton binding energies) indicate that the states are photoexcited since none of these energies fall in the thermal range. Furthermore, the estimated small negative values of Ec satisfactorily evidence the existence of the CT state for each dye molecule as predicted by the spatial separation of the hole and electron density distributions and their extent of overlap. A gradual enhancement of the hole–electron Coulomb attraction energy with the decaying of the DCT length is retained for the photoexcited states of D1 and D3 dyes. However, for dyes D2, D4, and D5, the delocalized nature of the density distributions of the hole and electron corresponding to the low-lying LE states induces an inconsistency between the Ec and DCT values.
    Since the quantum yield for the electron injection process depends on the kinetics of radiative and nonradiative decays of the excited states, as well as the quenching pathways of the excited states, the recognition of emission spectra of the sensitizers appears to be significant in predicting the efficiency of DSSC. Figure 4f illustrates the computed emission spectra of the dye D3 along with a comparison with the corresponding absorption maxima. The figure also represents key information related to the radiative lifetime of the absorption and the fluorescent states, calculated Stokes shift (red shift) of the fluorescent state, and the experimental data of the fluorescence maxima. (52,53) Similar pictures of the other dyes are available in the Supporting Information (Figure S7). The radiative lifetime for the absorption (τa) and fluorescence (τf) is computed as the inverse of the Einstein spontaneous emission coefficient (A21)(3.2.2)where |rk,k′|2 is the dipole strength of the absorption or the fluorescence state, and Ek,k′ is the corresponding excitation energy (k → k′). The computed emission maxima (Figures 4f and S7) are in very good agreement with the experimental photoluminescence data of the dyes. The reported τf values are obtained here by considering the relative quantum yield (Φf) as unity. The experimental Φf values of the present dyes are not available, but the reported Φf of several fluorescent dyes show that they are mostly less than 0.9. (78) In this respect, the actual τf should be greater than those computed by the TD-CAM-B3LYP (as τf (actual) = τf/Φf, neglecting the contribution of the nonradiative lifetime). The computed τf values are in a reasonable agreement with the 100 ps time-dependent photoluminescent spectra of the dyes measured within a pulse duration of 100 fs.
    The computed large values of the Stokes shift lying in the range of 127–175 nm are indicative of the structural flexibility upon excitation. The important geometric features of the optimized S1 state (i.e., the emission state) are shown in Table S1 in combination with the corresponding ground-state data. The optimized structures show that the dihedral angles Ψ1 of these dyes are not fully planar, although quite close to the π-bridge plane. This means the donor group TPA is not able to transfer the charge fully, although, in comparison to the ground-state Ψ1, the situation has improved in that respect. The acceptor part, on the other hand, is fully planar with respect to the π-bridge. These structural features together with the estimated augmented values of dipole moments confirm that the optimized S1 state of the dyes D1–D5 corresponds to a charge-transfer state. The predicted dipole moments for the emission state of these dyes are found to vary between 13.5 and 16.3 D (Table S4). Next, the τa and τf values are evaluated for both radiative and nonradiative decays with respect to the structural arrangements to elucidate the impact of π-spacer units on the radiative lifetimes of the photoexcited states of these D−π–A dyes. The computed τa values for the strong peaks appeared in the absorption spectra of dyes D1–D5 are reported in Table S2. The low-lying upper charge-transfer states are substantiated by their large μnorm values and much lower absorption lifetimes (Table S2). The decay of the photoexcited electrons from the upper CT state to the singlet ground state through interstate crossing is improbable here as the CT absorption state is lying in the UV region.
    The more probable situation is the nonradiative contribution of the upper CT state to the S1 state due to smaller τa values compared to that of the τf values of the S1 state. This is further supported by the predicted identical MO excitation components for the S1 state and upper CT state. A closer inspection of the calculated values of the contributions of MOs for the electronic excitations vindicates the weaker contribution of the CT absorption state to the S1 state through a probable nonradiative effect. This photophysics could be explained quite well through the schematic Jablonski diagram (Figure 5). The partial charge-transfer contribution to the S1 state during the excitation process probably makes these fluorescent states of the dyes a CT state, as observed through the optimized geometry of the S1 state.
    To further elucidate the impact of the inclusion of solvent–solute polarization within the framework of the SS model, the computed vertical emission energies using LR- and SS-CPCM/TD-CAM-B3LYP are compared in Table S4. The obtained results manifest that the emission maxima with the SS model are red-shifted by about 50 and 39 nm compared to the LR-CPCM method for the D1 and D2 dyes, respectively, while in the case of the D3–D5 dyes, the emission maxima are blue-shifted by 6–28 nm. Therefore, the deviations between the computed values of vertical emission energies employing the SS and LR schemes are negligible and lie within ±0.15 eV.

    3.3. Absorption and Emission Spectra of the Dye/(TiO2)9 Complexes

    The influence of small structural changes of the π-bridges on the photophysical properties of the DSSC sensitizers adsorbed onto the semiconductor surface has been ascertained by analyzing the low-lying excited states of the hybrid composites. Figure 6a shows the absorption spectra calculated at the CAM-B3LYP/6-31g(d) level of theory for the dye/(TiO2)9 complexes in the o-DCB solvent (ε: 10.0). The computed vertical excitation energies and associated excited-state properties such as oscillator and dipole strengths, and major contributions of the MOs for each transition are reported in Table S3.
    The hybrid composites exhibit similar absorption characteristics like the individual dyes, although the S1 states of these complexes are red-shifted with respect to the corresponding free dyes, as evident from Figure 6a. The strong peaks of the S1 states are located at the visible region, but few intense peaks, like for the free dyes, appeared at the near-ultraviolet (UV) regions. These upper states are very close in energy (almost degenerate) and are slightly blue/red-shifted with respect to free dyes (Tables S2 and S3). The isosurface plots of the hole–electron distributions for the various photoexcited states of the dye/TiO2 complexes are presented in Figure S8. The S1 state in most of these complexes emerges as the charge separation state, while several higher excited states correspond to the charge-transfer states likewise the isolated dyes. This is exemplified through the hole–electron density distribution maps for the excited S1 and S3 states of the D3/TiO2 complex (Figure 6b,c). The nature of the electronic excitations for each dye–semiconductor composite is further quantitatively assessed by computing different parameters viz. Δr index, S, DCT, μnorm, and Ec (Table 3). The identifications of S1 states of these complexes as the charge-separated one and the detection of real charge-transfer states above the S1 state are further justified by the predicted small and large μnorm values, respectively. Moreover, the μnorm values in Table 3 anticipate that there are several degenerate charge-transfer states for these complexes (unlike the free dyes), and these results comply with the isosurfaces of electron–hole distributions (Figures 6b,c and S8). The larger Δr, DCT, and Ec values for the various states (Table 3) also comply with the inferences drawn from the μnorm values of the respective states. The isosurface maps of the hole and electron centroids, as demonstrated in Figure 6d,e for the complexes D1/(TiO2)9 and D2/(TiO2)9, further support such excitation natures of these dyes. It is to be mentioned in this connection that the S1 state of D2, which was inferred as the LE state, is transformed to the charge-separated species due to the adsorption on the (TiO2)9 surface.
    Table 3. Estimated Δr Index, Overlapping Extent of the Hole and Electron (S), Distance between the Centroid of the Hole and Electron (DCT), Variation of Dipole Moment with Respect to the Ground State (μnorm), and the Hole–Electron Coulomb Attractive Energy (EC) for the Low-Lying Excited States of the Dye/(TiO2)9 Complexes
    dyetransitionΔr (Å)SDCT (Å)μnorm (au)EC (eV)
    D1S0 → S19.250.403.336.30–3.13
     S0 → S413.340.417.4314.03–2.05
     S0 → S716.740.1711.1420.89–1.59
     S0 → S89.360.454.207.93–2.44
    D2S0 → S111.480.413.887.37–3.01
     S0 → S416.610.466.8413.03–2.40
     S0 → S59.540.455.3910.25–2.44
    D3S0 → S111.360.433.196.02–3.15
     S0 → S312.620.457.6814.46–2.07
     S0 → S48.690.304.598.63–0.11
     S0 → S69.970.474.768.99–2.20
    D4S0 → S113.320.443.326.33–3.16
     S0 → S214.020.495.069.60–2.35
     S0 → S315.170.3311.3221.43–1.80
     S0 → S49.220.364.498.55–2.78
     S0 → S511.410.494.458.45–2.30
    D5S0 → S110.840.423.025.70–3.33
     S0 → S413.400.505.9311.18–2.38
     S0 → S514.970.3010.0718.94–1.91
     S0 → S615.810.329.7418.32–1.93
     S0 → S717.800.1611.6922.14–1.78
    Figure 6f unveils the computed emission spectra of the D3/TiO2 complex followed by a comparison with the corresponding absorption maxima and the information related to the radiative lifetime of the absorption and the fluorescent states and calculated Stokes shift (red shift) of the fluorescent state. The comparative studies of the simulated absorption and emission spectra for the other dyes are elucidated in the Supporting Information (Figure S9). The predicted τa and τf values are also depicted. The computed Eem, f, |rk,k′|2, τf, and μS1 corresponding to the relaxed S1 state of the pristine photosensitizers and the dye/(TiO2)9 composites in the o-DCB solvent are reported in Table S4. The predicted emission maxima are also compared with the experimental data. The experimental photoluminescence data of the complexes Dn/(TiO2)9 (n = 1, 2) do not show any appreciable shift with respect to the individual D1 and D2 dyes. The photoluminescence spectra of the similar complexes with the dyes D3 and D4, on the other hand, are red-shifted with respect to the individual dyes. The computed emission maxima for all of the complexes show red shifts with respect to the experimental peak positions, but the broad nature of the experimental spectral band allows the computed emission maxima to be quite reasonable. The experimental photoluminescence data for the D5/(TiO2)9 complex is not available. The computed τf values (using Φf = 1) are smaller than those of the individual dyes; however, one could estimate larger values of τf if the Φf values are considered in the range of 0.6–0.8.
    The calculated Stokes shift values for the studied dye/TiO2 complexes are found to vary between 89 and 150 nm, suggesting less structural rigidity upon photoexcitation. The important geometric features of the optimized S1 state (i.e., the emission state) of the composites are shown in Table S1 in combination with the corresponding ground-state data. The optimized structures manifest that the dihedral angles Ψ1/Ψ2 of these dyes, except for the dye D1, do not change appreciably with respect to the TPA units of free dyes. Thus, the TPA moiety is not able to transfer the charge effectively in the dye–TiO2 complexes. The CAA moiety in these complexes is fully planar with respect to the π-bridge, as revealed by the Φ1/Φ2. The estimated large dipole moment values, lying between 28.5 and 34.8 D (Table S4), for the relaxed structures of the corresponding S1 emission state further evidence the onset of charge-transfer state analogous to the pristine dyes. The de-excitation process could be explained by adopting similar consideration made for the individual dyes, as discussed earlier through the Jablonski diagram, and by accounting the τa-values of the low-lying upper charge-transfer states (Table S3, Supporting Information) and the common occurrence of the MO transition coefficients in both S1 and CT states. The most interesting situation in these cases relates to the smaller fluorescence lifetime of the complexes with respect to the individual dyes. This feature would contribute to the easier hole–particle transport from the dye to the (TiO2)9 part of the complex and is an important factor in the solar cell activities of these systems.
    To account for the dynamical solvent effect, the emission energies are further evaluated within the SS scheme and compared with those obtained by the LR-CPCM/TD-CAM-B3LYP method in Table S4. The estimated errors in computing emission energies for the dye–TiO2 systems with the LR-CPCM method are found to be very small (within 0.15 eV).

    3.4. Parameters Affecting DSSC Efficiency of the Chosen Dyes

    The photophysical properties of the dyes and dye–TiO2 complexes discussed so far have a direct effect on the photoelectric conversion efficiency of a DSSC as described through eq 1.1. Next, we delve into a quantitative analysis of key parameters influencing the Jsc and Voc of DSSC. The dependence of the structural modification of π-spacer units on the charge separation and recombination mechanism at the dye–semiconductor interface has been examined by performing the TD-CAM-B3LYP-based computations. We subsequently explored the charge injection efficiency as a function of the dye’s building block through the estimations of the exciton dissociation time and cold electron lifetime from the relaxed excited-state geometry on the potential energy hypersurface.

    3.4.1. Dye Properties Influencing Jsc

    The short-circuit current density, Jsc, is related to the electron dynamics phenomena of a working DSSC device. It depends on the light-harvesting efficiency (LHE), the kinetics of electron injection, dye regeneration, and charge transport within the DSSC. Thus, Jsc is directly dependent on the dye properties. The estimation of Jsc combines all of these factors through the following expression (49)(3.4.1.1)The theoretical estimation of Jsc from such expression is qualitative as the parameter IPCE(λ) (photon to electron conversion efficiency) is equal to the product of three components (LHE(λ) × ϕinj × ϕcoll) [ϕinj: quantum yield of electron injection, ϕcoll: electron collection efficiency] and is expressed in terms of LHE(λ) only by approximating the product of ϕinj and ϕcoll as unity. The term LHE(λ) is usually expressed as (1 – I/I0) (I0: intensity of the light absorbed by the sample; I: intensity of the emitted light after absorption), (79) and from Beer–Lambert’s law, it is simply (1 – 10–A), where A is the absorbance. This is a valid approximation since everything is considered in the solution phase (in the o-DCB solvent). For practical theoretical computations, A is approximated as the f of the highest absorption wavelength (λmax, S1 state). The magnitude of f for S1 states of the dyes is quite high (Table S2), and (1 – 10–A) term for the dyes is close to unity. Considering Pin in eq 3.4.1.1 as 100 mW/cm2 according to the experiment, (52) the Jsc term is usually computed here for its maximum limit (Jscmax), and these Jscmax values are reported in Table 4 along with the experimental values. Such approximate calculations cannot reproduce the experimental data accurately. The predicted trends in the Jsc for the dyes D1, D2, and D4 correlate linearly with the experimental measurements, while those for D3 and D5 do not. This puts some uncertainty in the theoretically computed Jsc values. Most of the papers do not report computed Jsc values because of these uncertainties; rather, factors affecting Jsc are mostly discussed.
    Table 4. Estimated Oxidation Potential of the Ground (Eoxdye) and Excited (Eoxdye*) States, Thermodynamic Driving Forces of Electron Injection Obtained from Unrelaxed (ΔGinj) and Relaxed (ΔGinjemi) Excited States, Regeneration of Oxidized Dyes (ΔGreg), Light-Harvesting Efficiencies (LHE), and Theoretical Maximum Limiting Values of the Short-Circuit Current Density (Jscmax) for All of the DSSC Sensitizers
    dyeEoxdye (eV)λmax (eV)Eoxdye* (eV)ΔGinj (eV)ΔGinjemi (eV)ΔGreg (eV)LHEJscmax (mA/cm2)Jsc (exp)a
    D15.112.762.35–1.65–1.04–0.310.98735.747.66
    D25.002.682.32–1.68–0.94–0.200.99437.1210.10
    D35.042.652.39–1.61–0.98–0.240.99337.4016.50
    D44.942.612.33–1.67–1.02–0.140.99738.1211.80
    D55.062.742.32–1.68–0.97–0.260.99036.0817.54
    a

    Refs (52,53).

    One of the factors affecting Jsc is ϕinj in eq 3.4.1.1. It is a measure of the efficiency of electron injection, and instead of approximating the product ϕinj × ϕcoll to unity, ϕinj could be calculated in terms of the thermodynamic driving force (ΔGinj) for the transfer of electrons from the photoexcited dye molecules to the conduction band (CB) of the TiO2 cluster using the following relation 3.4.1.2(3.4.1.2)where Eoxdye* is the excited-state oxidation potential of dyes, and ECB = −4.0 eV. Two approaches could be used to evaluate Eoxdye* depending on the mode of electron injection. These two modes could be classified as the injection of electrons to the semiconductor through the unrelaxed excited state of the dye molecule (i.e., the absorption maximum of the S1 state) and the relaxed form of the excited state (i.e., the emission maximum of the S1 state). The first approximation is valid if the electron injection mechanism from the photoexcited dye to the TiO2 semiconductor takes place prior to the relaxation process. (43) Thus, Eoxdye* could be evaluated through the relation 3.4.1.3 as(3.4.1.3)where Eoxdye is the ground-state oxidation potential (HOMO energy of the dye), and ES1 is the absorption maxima energy of the S1 state. The second approximation relies on the relaxed form of the excited state if the emission state is quite stable, and ES1 in eq 3.4.1.3 should be the energy of the photoluminescence maxima of the dye in the fully optimized geometry. The ΔGinj computed through eq 3.4.1.2 in such cases is abbreviated as ΔGinjemi. The expression of Jsc used in eq 3.4.1.1 is a working expression with many approximations. The general expression of Jsc involves another term ηreg, which is related to the driving force of regeneration (ΔGreg) between the oxidized dye and the electrolyte (I–/I3–). The situation is related to the reaction step (A3) as discussed earlier. In principle, this parameter also affects the performance of Jsc in DSSC and could be evaluated using the expression 3.4.1.4 below(3.4.1.4)Here, Eredox is the redox potential of the redox couple (I–/I3–) [∼4.8 eV], and Edye is the ground-state oxidation potential of the isolated dye. The calculated values of ΔGinj, ΔGinjemi, and ΔGreg together with the parameters for their computations are shown in Table 4. The solvent, o-DCB, has a very marginal effect on these parameters (Table S5, Supporting Information) with respect to their gas-phase values, and thus only the gas-phase data is considered for analyzing the photoelectron conversion efficiency of DSSC.
    The ΔGreg values for these dyes are estimated to lie in between −0.2 and −0.31 eV. Only the dye D4 has ΔGreg of −0.14 eV. According to the earlier experimental evidence on DSSC dyes, (80) the dye regeneration for D1–D3 and D5 should be >96%. Only the dye D4 should have a somewhat smaller regeneration value (∼90%). On the other hand, ΔGinj for all of these dyes varies from −1.65 to −1.68 eV. Thus, according to the previous experiments and theoretical estimates, (81,82) the ϕinj is spontaneous and tends to be 1 (∼100%) since they are quite high (>−0.2 eV). The computed ΔGinjemi values in Table 4 also point to the same ϕinj, as they are much greater than −0.2 eV. The computed ΔGinj, ΔGinjemi, and ΔGreg thus reflect some ideal situation for the dyes, where electron injection and regeneration rates are similar. This, in turn, would generate similar Jsc values. Although the theoretical Jscmax values (Table 4) preserve a linear correlation with these parameters, the experimental situations are different as compared in Table 4. Thus, a more accurate approach involving the explicit electron-transfer rate calculation would be required to investigate these properties.

    3.4.2. Factors Affecting Voc

    The open-circuit voltage, Voc, is modulated by the quasi-Fermi level of the semiconductor under illumination, as well as the redox potential of the electrolyte. The quasi-Fermi level of the semiconductor is further guided by the shift of the TiO2 conduction band energy and the charge density accumulated in TiO2. Because of the presence of an appreciable amount of redox species during the DSSC operation, (83) the dependence of Voc on the redox potential appears to be insubstantial. Quantitatively, Voc is expressed as (43)(3.4.2.1)With(3.4.2.2)In the above expressions, ECB is the conduction band (CB) edge of the semiconductor (TiO2), Eredox is the redox potential of the electrolyte (I–/I3–), kT is the thermal energy, q is the unit charge, nc is the number of electrons in the CB, NCB is the accessible density of the CB state, ΔECB is the shift of CB when the dye is adsorbed on the semiconductor surface, ε0 and ε are, respectively, the permittivity of the vacuum and dielectric constant of the organic monolayer, and μnormal is the component of the dipole moment when the dye is grafted on the surface of the semiconductor.
    Table 1 displays the computed values of the shift of the CB of TiO2 (ΔECB,TiO2) and the dyes (ΔECB,dye) together with the adsorption energies Eads. The calculated dipole moment component values (μS1) due to the adsorption of dyes over the (TiO2)9-cluster surface corresponding to the relaxed S1 state are reported in Table S4. The ΔECB term is generally expressed as the sum of the shift introduced by the solvent, ions, and adsorbed dyes. Under the same experimental condition, the solvent and ion influences could be considered as constants, and thus ΔECB is determined from the total density of states (TDOS) of the semiconductor or dyes and the partial density of states (PDOS) of the hybrid complexes near their respective conduction bands. Figures S10 and S11 represent the computed TDOS and PDOS spectra of the (TiO2)9-cluster, dyes D1–D5, and their hybrid complexes from which the Δ ECB,TiO2 and ΔECB,dye were computed. The values of ΔECB,TiO2 and ΔECB,dye correlate with the changes in the experimental Voc for the complexes with the dyes D1–D4, but the changes of these parameters for D5 are not consistent with the measured Voc, as revealed from the obtained results (Table 1). A higher value of these parameters was found for D5, although its Voc is comparable with the dyes D2–D4. The μS1 values, on the other hand, are found to correlate well with the Voc values except for D2 (Figure S12). The computed Eads values of these dyes on (TiO2)9 surface are not very informative in correlating their effect on the changes of Voc.

    3.4.3. Analysis of the Charge-Transfer Processes

    3.4.3.1. Intramolecular Energy Transfer
    After photoexcitation, the created exciton (D*A) in the DSSC photosensitizer can migrate to the (DA*) state or separate into the (D+A–) state by electron transfer and the (D–A+) state by hole transfer. The understanding of the CT and energy transfer among these mixed states necessitates the calculations of the electron- and hole-hopping rates (ke and kh, respectively) deploying the Marcus–Hush eq 3.4.3.1 (84,85)(3.4.3.1)where JDA is the electronic coupling between the dye (donor, D) and (TiO2)9 (acceptor, A), λ is either the electron (λe)- or hole (λh)-hopping reorganization energies for the evaluation of the corresponding k values (ke or kh), T is the temperature (absolute scale), and kB is the Boltzmann constant. The λ-terms are computed as (86)(3.4.3.2)(3.4.3.3)where E0– and E0+ are the energies of the anion and cation in the optimized ground-state structure of the dye molecule, respectively. E– and E+ refer to the energies of the relaxed geometries of the anionic and cationic states of the respective dye molecule. E–0 and E+0 are the energies of the neutral molecule calculated using the optimized geometries of the anionic and cationic states, respectively, while E0 is the energy of the neutral dye molecule for its fully optimized geometry. The solvent effects in such cases are not included since it has been found that the dye properties in Table 5 are solvent-independent. However, the solvent effect is included in the calculation of the JDA terms under the Förster energy-transfer formalism. (56) The JDA term in eq 3.4.3.1 was computed through the TD-CAM-B3LYP scheme including the CPCM solvation model (87) as follows(3.4.3.4)where JDACoul, JDAXC, and JDAOvlp terms include the solvent-mediated Coulomb, exchange (possibly including the correlation effect), and overlap interactions, respectively. These three terms consider the effect of coupling distances on JDA during the adsorption between the donor (dye) and the acceptor (TiO2 cluster). The last term, JDACPCM, describes a three-body coulombic interaction as chromophores ↔ solvent ↔ chromophore. Thus, this calculation procedure includes both the reaction and screening effect due to the solvent in a unified model merging the Förster–Dexter-type approaches.
    Table 5. Estimated First-Order Electron Coupling Strength between the Donor and Acceptor (JDA) for Intramolecular Excitation Energy Transfer (EET), Reorganization Energy of the Electron (λe) and Hole (λh), Electron-Hopping Rate (ke) and Lifetime (τe), and Hole-Hopping Rate (kh) and Lifetime (τh) for All of the Studied Dyes
    dyeJDA (eV)λe (eV)λh (eV)ke (s–1)τe (s)kh (s–1)τh (s)
    D115.25 × 10–40.340.252.44 × 1094.09 × 10–106.85 × 1091.46 × 10–10
    D289.44 × 10–40.340.328.40 × 10101.19 × 10–111.05 × 10119.51 × 10–12
    D324.43 × 10–40.330.257.01 × 1091.43 × 10–101.76 × 10105.69 × 10–11
    D423.78 × 10–40.320.327.44 × 1091.34 × 10–107.44 × 1091.34 × 10–10
    D53.44 × 10–40.370.278.89 × 1071.12 × 10–82.76 × 1083.63 × 10–9
    The computed values of JDA together with λe, λh, ke, and kh are presented in Table 5. Ten roots of both (TiO2)9 cluster and the dyes D1–D5 were considered during the computations of JDA in the excitation (exciton in solid state) energy-transfer (EET) analyses so that the complete span of the absorption spectra of (TiO2)9, as well as the dyes, was fully covered. The foot of the S1 state of (TiO2)9 (294 nm) was considered during the analysis. The consideration of the 10 roots also reckons the region near the emission maxima (∼600 nm) of the dyes. Thus, all of the probable effects of the excited states of (TiO2)9 and the dyes, affecting the magnitude of the JDA term in eq 3.4.3.1, were accounted for. The computed JDA parameters in Table 5 include only the S1(TiO2 cluster)–S1(dye) interactions. The JDA terms were also computed using the absorption maxima of the CT states of dyes and the S1 state of TiO2. The computed values were in the 10–5–10–6 eV order, indicating very weak interactions between the dye and TiO2 and were not considered for the subsequent calculations of the electron and hole-hopping rates. Within the framework of the Marcus–Hush formalism, the hole-hopping rate (kh) is estimated to be faster than the electron-hopping rate (ke) for each photosensitizer. The inverse of these rate constants is the measure of lifetimes of such charge carrier transfer process, and the calculated lifetimes for the electron hopping (τe) and hole hopping (τh) are presented in Table 5. The τe values for different dye systems are always larger than the corresponding τh.
    The electron- and hole-hopping lifetimes (τe/h) are related to their respective diffusion lengths (L) of holes/electrons through the relation (88)(3.4.3.5)where D is the diffusion coefficient. The equation suggests that the longer lifetime is related to the higher diffusion length of the carrier (electron or hole) and thus the carrier can survive longer without recombining. This could be understood by considering the electronic features of the dyes. The isosurface maps of the dyes (Figure 4d,e) and dye–TiO2 clusters (Figure 6d,e) indicate that the hole and electron centroids lying on the isolated dyes do not change position during the adsorption onto the TiO2 surface. Thus, the hopping length L in the present cases could be related to the distance combining DCT (Table 2) and R (Table 1), as the electrons need to hop these distances to get injected on TiO2. The (DCT + R) value is smallest for the dye D2, and the τe and τh are fastest for it, while the (DCT + R) value maximizes for D5, and τe and τh values show that they are slowest for these dyes. The calculated hopping rates of the dyes corroborate well with the predicted hopping length order for the other dyes (D3 < D4 < D1). These features, thus, play an important role in limiting the Voc values. Although these computed hopping rates (and L values) are not following the experimental Voc order properly, it is accounting for the highest Voc of D5. A further problem is the higher Voc of D1 with respect to D2, but the difference is small, and the computed τ and L (DCT + R) values still indicate them as less efficient dyes with respect to the others.
    3.4.3.2. Analysis of Interfacial Electronic Injection
    The second limiting factor of Voc is governed by the competition between the electron injection and recombination rates at the dye–semiconductor interface. Both these rates could be computed through the Marcus theory at high-temperature limit. (57) The electron injection rate between the dye and semiconductor is calculated as(3.4.3.6)(3.4.3.7)The parameters λe and λh are already defined in eqs 3.4.3.2 and 3.4.3.3. The kB and T are the same as in eq 3.4.3.1. The ΔG terms were discussed before, and they are defined as ΔGinj and ΔGinjemi corresponding to the unrelaxed and relaxed excited states, respectively. For the simulation of the interfacial charge-transfer process, the generalized Mulliken–Hush (GMH) method (54) has been deployed to estimate the charge-transfer integral. Within the GMH formalism, the electronic coupling matrix between two adiabatic states (S0 and Sn) is computed as(3.4.3.8)where μtr is the transition dipole moment, ΔE corresponds to the energy gap, and Δμ refers to the dipole moment difference between the initial adiabatic state and the final one. For a photoinduced charge-transfer process at the dye–semiconductor interface, the energy difference ΔE could be computed as(3.4.3.9)where ETiO2CB is the reduction potential of the semiconductor, and Edye+ and Edye* are the energy of the dye cation in the excited state and the energy of the relaxed excited state, respectively. The difference between the last two terms refers to the oxidation potential of the dye in the excited state (Eoxdye*), and consequently, ΔE in eq 3.4.3.9 corresponds to the injection free energy (ΔGinj). The Marcus eq 3.4.3.6 could be compared with the Eyring reaction rate equation, and it could be immediately found that the exponential term is analogous to the partition function, and the term inside, excluding the kBT term, could be considered as the barrier heights of the electron injection and charge recombination processes. These barriers are defined as G* terms and could be computed as(3.4.3.10)The G* values are tabulated in Tables 6 and 7 as ΔGinj* and ΔGinjemi* along with the λ values.
    Table 6. Estimated Total Reorganization Energy (λtotal), Electronic Coupling Under the Generalized Mulliken–Hush (GMH) Formalism (VDAGMH), Barrier Heights of the Electron Injection (ΔGinj*), Charge-Transfer Rate (kinj), and Lifetime (τinj) for the Photoinduced Electron Injection Process Occurring from the Unrelaxed Excited State of the Photosensitizera
    dyeλtotal (eV)VDAGMH (eV)ΔGinj* (eV)kinj (s–1)τinj (ns)τinjexp (ps)τeexp (ps)
    D10.590.7580.4761.12 × 1088.960.6823.56
    D20.660.8390.3943.15 × 1090.321.4613.63
    D30.580.7730.4572.44 × 1084.110.7419.30
    D40.640.7770.4141.24 × 1090.800.8415.07
    D50.640.7600.4238.68 × 1081.151.49172.0
    a

    The experimental values of the cold electron injection time (τinjexp) and cold electron lifetime (τeexp) are also represented for comparison.

    Table 7. Computed Electron Coupling Strength within the GMH Framework (VDAGMH), Barrier Heights of the Electron Injection (ΔGinjemi*), Charge-Transfer Rate (kinjemi), and Lifetime (τinjemi) for the DSSC Electron Injection Process Occurring from the Relaxed Excited State of the Photosensitizer
    dyeVDAGMH (eV)ΔGinjemi* (eV)kinjemi (s–1)τinjemi (fs)
    D11.0520.0868.57 × 10141.17
    D20.9560.0305.95 × 10150.17
    D30.9910.0691.48 × 10150.68
    D40.9680.0562.19 × 10150.46
    D50.9830.0423.87 × 10150.26
    Both the unrelaxed and relaxed excited states are considered to predict the electron injection rates in DSSC since the relative contribution of the ultrafast injection path is not yet clear. The computed values of the electron coupling strengths within the GMH approximation together with the barrier heights of electron injection, rate constant, and lifetime of the electron injection process emanating from the unrelaxed and relaxed excited-state geometries are reported in Tables 6 and 7, respectively. The experimental cold electron injection lifetime (52) and cold electron lifetime for the dyes D1–D5 in the dye/TiO2 system are shown in Table 6. The electron injection occurs chiefly after the relaxation of the dye molecule upon photoirradiation, as evident by the calculated electron injection rates. Furthermore, the electron injection from the unrelaxed excited state is prompted by an electronic coupling weaker than that evaluated for the injection from the lowest excited state of the photosensitizers. Albeit the Marcus theory provides relatively realistic kinj values ascertained from the relaxed excited state of the lowest energy within the GMH formalism, the trends in the predicted time scale for the electron injection to the CB of TiO2 are not in good agreement with the experimentally measured cold electron injection lifetimes. This discrepancy may be attributed to the ambivalence regarding the conformational space of the chromophores and the exponential functional dependence of the kinj on the ΔGinj and λ values. The predicted λ values using eq 3.4.3.7 and defined λ’s in the Marcus eq 3.4.3.6 closely resemble each other only in the linear dielectric response regime. Moreover, eq 3.4.3.6 is valid for the weak coupling between the S0 and Sn states at sufficiently high temperature and when a classical description of the reaction coordinate is assumed.
    The electron injection rate could also be estimated employing the Newns–Anderson (NA) model (58) in a much simpler way without going through the Marcus technique involving the detailed configuration interaction procedures. The NA technique allows the evaluation of the adsorption effects on the sensitizer electronic levels. Only the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of the dye/TiO2 composite are considered, and they are characterized in terms of the energy shift relative to the free dye and the lifetime broadening ℏΔ. The term Δ is the half-width at the half-maximum of the dye’s PDOS coupled to the continuum of the semiconductor (TiO2) CB states. The contribution pi to the dye’s LUMO PDOS is defined as (46)(3.4.3.11)where cijX are the expansion coefficients of the complex molecular orbitals on the basis functions of atom X belonging to the dye. The width of the LUMO broadening is defined as (46)(3.4.3.12)With(3.4.3.13)where εi is the energy of the orbital corresponding to pi, and ELUMOads is the energy of the dye’s LUMO adsorbed on the TiO2 cluster. The electron-transfer lifetime, which is equivalent to the electron injection lifetime, is computed as (46)(3.4.3.14)The calculated τinj, along with ELUMOads and Δ, for the dyes D1–D5 are presented in Table 8. The results reveal that the computed trends in the interfacial electron injection lifetimes are in conformity with the experimental cold electron injection time (Table 6), although the computed lifetimes are much faster (femtosecond order) compared to the experimental data. Thus, it is evident that the electron injection is a nonadiabatic charge-transfer (CT) phenomenon and needs a barrier for electron injection, which is not considered in the Newns–Anderson model.
    Table 8. Computed Key Parameters for Estimating the Interfacial Electron Injection Lifetime (τinjinter), Using the Newns–Anderson Method, Due to the Adsorption of DSSC Sensitizers on the Semiconductor Surface
    dyeELUMO,adsa (eV)Δb (eV)τinjinter (fs)
    D1–3.680.3800.866
    D2–3.690.3590.917
    D3–3.520.4140.795
    D4–3.540.4070.809
    D5–3.720.3750.878
    a

    ELUMO,ads represents the position of the LUMO level of the adsorbate in the dye/(TiO2)9 complexes.

    b

    Δ denotes the half-width at half-maximum of the adsorbate’s PDOS corresponding to the Lorentzian distribution of the LMMO level of dyes after the attachment on the TiO2 surface.

    To obtain a more realistic electron injection rate, the dependence of the electron-transfer process on the varying donor–acceptor distance has been accounted in terms of the attenuation factor β through the exponential distance dependence of the electronic coupling between the donor and acceptor, |V|2 ∝ exp (−βr). Within the semiclassical approach of the charge-transfer kinetics, the electron injection rate is calculated by considering the following simplified form of the Marcus theory, (89) which concerns with the nonadiabatic electron transfer between two centers confined to a fixed distance and orientation(3.4.3.15)where A is constant and considered to be 2.5 × 10–2. The attenuation factor β, which depends on the probe wavelength, is obtained from the empirical values in the donor–bridge–acceptor systems with conjugated bridges. (89) Since electron transfers from the LUMO orbital of the dye to the CB of TiO2, the transfer distance is estimated from the distance between the TiO2 surface and the CAA anchoring group. The driving force for the electron transfer (ΔG0) is computed from the difference between the LUMO of the photosensitizer and the CB of TiO2. Table 9 displays the predicted nonadiabatic charge-transfer rates and injection lifetimes. The computed injection lifetimes are comparable with the experimental data in terms of the temporal scale. The measured values of τinj for dyes D4 and D5 are found to correlate well with the experimental ones.
    Table 9. Predicted Key Parameters for Deducing Nonadiabatic Charge-Transfer Rate of Electron Injection
    dyerinj (Å)β (Å–1)V (eV)λtotal (eV)ΔGinj* (eV)kinj (s–1)τinj (ps)
    D11.970.41.14 × 10–20.590.2581.09 × 101092.07
    D21.950.41.15 × 10–20.660.1604.66 × 10112.15
    D32.060.41.10 × 10–20.580.1931.29 × 10117.74
    D42.060.41.10 × 10–20.640.1271.64 × 10120.61
    D51.970.41.14 × 10–20.640.1506.90 × 10111.45
    3.4.3.3. Analysis of Electron Recombination
    Next, we place emphasis on the quantitative analysis of the electron recombination kinetics, which is proposed to be a limiting factor of Voc. The recombination process in DSSC could be between the injected electron and the dye cation or between the injected electron in the conduction band of the TiO2 surface and the redox couple (I–/I3–) in the electrolyte. The first process is the so-called inner path recombination, and the second process is known as the outer path recombination. We have investigated only the inner path recombination in the present computational study. After the electron injection to the CB of TiO2, the electrons have a remarkable distribution in the CB of the semiconductor. If the accumulated electrons are not properly transported to the transparent oxide electrode, there is an ample scope to recombine with the holes present in the dyes. The electron transfer from TiO2 to the photosensitizer is guided by the energy difference between the CB minimum of the semiconductor and the HOMO of the dye, as delineated in Figure 7. For the estimation of the recombination rate (krec) using the Marcus theory, the reorganization energy λ is assumed to be the same as calculated for the injection process. Due to the bell-shaped dependence of the krec on ΔG, the potential difference distribution has been computed from the relaxed excited-state geometry in the presence of the o-DCB solvent.
