Since the recombination process is purely not an electron-transfer process between two weakly coupled diabatic states, the solvent-mediated electronic coupling strength is determined within the EET formalism based on a DFT-derived wave function employing the time-dependent variational approach. The calculated barrier heights (ΔGrec*), rate constants (krec), and lifetimes (τrec) for the charge recombination process are provided in Table 10. The predicted time scales for charge recombination are in conformity with the experimental estimations obtained from the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). (52,53) The insertion of a thiophene unit between the π-bridge and the acceptor unit CAA augments the barrier height, especially in the case of dye D3, and consequently retards the recombination process during the effective charge injection, leading to the escalation of the photostability of the dye. As evident by the computed kinetic parameters, the optimum balance between the charge injection and recombination upon photoexcitation is mainly responsible for the enhanced solar cell efficiency of D3, which is in accordance with the experimental observation. (53)
    Table 10. Predicted Key Parameters for Deducing Nonadiabatic Charge-Transfer Rate of Electron Recombination Occurring from the Relaxed Excited State of the Photosensitizer
    dyeΔGrec* (eV)krec (s–1)τrec (s)τrecexp,a (s)
    D10.6732.14 × 10–14.68 
    D20.7424.60 × 10–12.17 
    D30.8456.79 × 10–41.47 × 103 
    D40.7661.34 × 10–27.47 × 101 
    D50.6915.13 × 10–31.95 × 1028.69 × 103
    a

    Ref (53).

    3.4.3.4. Analysis of Cold Electron Injection Efficiency
    To validate the efficiency and robustness of the quantitative estimations of the charge injection and recombination kinetics in predicting the potential DSSC photosensitizer, we further evaluated the efficiency of cold electron injection deploying the Onsager (90)–Braun (91) theory. Based on the earlier study, the efficiency could be computed as(3.4.3.16)where τinj and τel are the cold electron injection lifetime (exciton dissociation time) and cold electron lifetime, respectively. The adopted model was previously employed for the DSSC to estimate the injection efficiency, (52) as well as for the polymer junction solar cells (92) to compute the polaron-pair separation yields. The τinj values are estimated from eq 3.4.3.15, as reported in Table 9. The clod electron lifetimes are evaluated using eq 3.4.3.1. The key parameters used to compute the ηcal are presented in Table S6. The calculated η values follow the trend D1 < D2 < D3 < D4 < D5. It indicates that the electron injection is fostered by the insertion of thiophene units between the CAA and the branched alkyl-substituted TTAR-based π-bridges. Next, the computed cold electron injection efficiencies are compared with the experimentally measured quantities of the DSSC performance parameters viz. Jsc, Voc, and PCE (%). The correlation plots for each case are depicted in Figure 8. As demonstrated, except for dye D4, the excellent consistency with the experiment elucidates the competency of the semiclassical analysis of the nonadiabatic charge-transfer process at the dye–semiconductor interface within the framework of the Marcus theory.

    4. Conclusions

    ARTICLE SECTIONS
    Jump To
    The DFT- and TD-DFT-based methods have been exploited to investigate the structural and optoelectronic properties of few D−π–A dyes involving the asymmetric π-spacer units. The subtle interplay between the structural modulation of the photosensitizers and the extent of the electrostatic and charge-transfer effects at the dye–semiconductor interface has been evaluated by accounting the mode of adsorption of the dyes on the (101) surface of the TiO2 cluster model. The substantial differences in the electrostatic and charge-transfer effects due to the anchoring of dye molecules on the semiconductor surface are derived from the calculated dipole moments, MO eigenvalues, electrostatic potential differences, projected density of state spectra, and localized orbital locator analysis. The robust interaction between the dye and the TiO2 surface through the formation of the Ti–O chemical bond is substantiated by the estimated large values of adsorption energies. The simulated absorption and emission spectra of the isolated photosensitizers and the modeled dye–TiO2 assemblies in the o-DCB solvent using the LR TD-DFT method with the CAM-B3LYP hybrid functional are found to correlate well with the experimental photoluminescence data. The low-lying charge-separated and charge-transferred states are identified via the computed values of charge-transfer distances, electron–hole overlap integrals, dipole moments, and exciton binding energies. The S1 states corresponding to the optical absorption spectra of all of the dyes and dye–TiO2 composites are ascertained to be the charge-separated ones. The real CT states were always some upper state (S3/S4), and the decay of these photoexcited CT states occurs through the probable nonradiative process. The emission state corresponding to the S1 state of each pristine dye and dye–TiO2 complex brings out to be the CT state, as evident by the computed higher dipole moment values. Notably, the emission states have a higher lifetime compared to the absorption states. Thus, it indicates that the charge-transfer process in such DSSC photosensitizers takes place from the emission state.
    Next, we emphasize on the quantitative estimations of the crucial factors influencing the Jsc and Voc parameters of DSSC. Due to the exclusion of the consideration of the electron injection efficiency and charge collection efficiency explicitly, the predicted maximum limiting values of Jsc through the computations of the light-harvesting efficiency of the DSSC sensitizers show somewhat deviations relative to the experimental trends. The calculated parameters such as dipole moment and the shift of the CB of TiO2 upon adsorption are in conformity with the measured Voc for linear alkyl-substituted TTAR-based sensitizers. Within the framework of the Marcus theory, the impacts of the π-spacer units on the exciton formation and migration processes are assessed by analyzing the CT and energy-transfer rates, which, in turn, rely on the meticulous excited-state structural relaxation and determination of the electronic coupling incorporating the effects of solvation through the CPCM model. The computed lifetimes for the hopping type of charge-transfer processes indicate that the electron- and hole-hopping rates are highly competitive in such DSSC sensitizers as the magnitudes of τe and τh are significantly influenced by the charge carrier diffusion length. The semiclassical analysis of the interfacial charge-transfer process using the Marcus model demonstrates an ultrafast photoelectron injection at a time scale of ps, which corroborates well with the experimental cold electron injection lifetimes. The calculated results regarding the charge recombination kinetics indicate that the insertion of a thiophene unit between the π-bridge (TTAR) and the acceptor unit (CAA) effectively retards the recombination process. This is in accordance with the results obtained from the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy. Furthermore, the computed cold electron injection efficiency employing predicted electron injection and hopping lifetimes reveals a linear correlation with the key parameters controlling the DSSC device performance. The combined strategies involving applications of the rate theories and electronic structure calculations could be helpful in designing promising DSSC sensitizers through the optimization of photoinduced charge-transfer and energy-transfer processes.

      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 110 (11), 6817-6855CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review of polyphenylene-based materials for org. solar cells. The first part provides a general introduction to different cell structures and their practical characterizations, including flat-heterojunction, bulk-heterojunction and dye-sensitized solar cells. In the second part, the focus is on polyphenylene-based materials, including one-dimensional polyphenylenes or oligophenylene rod-type compds., two-dimensional polyphenylenes (esp., perylenes and their derivs.), and polyphenylene dendrimers.

      Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Hagfeldt, Anders; Boschloo, Gerrit; Sun, Licheng; Kloo, Lars; Pettersson, Henrik
      Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States) (2010), 110 (11), 6595-6663CODEN: CHREAY; ISSN:0009-2665. (American Chemical Society)
      A review on dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). Some brief notes on solar energy in general and DSC in particular are given, followed by a discussion of the operational principles of DSC (energetics and kinetics). Then, the development of material components and some specific exptl. techniques to characterize DSC are described. The current status of module development is also discussed, and finally a brief future outlook is given.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3cXhtFChs77M&md5=e6727377e1d3eec4c6c6d78276ff77a1
      open URL
    3. 3
      Labat, F.; Bahers, T.; Ciofini, I.; Adamo, C. First-Principles Modeling of Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: Challenges and Perspectives. Acc. Chem. Res. 2012, 45, 1268– 1277,  DOI: 10.1021/ar200327w
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      3
      First-Principles Modeling of Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: Challenges and Perspectives
      Labat, Frederic; Le Bahers, Tangui; Ciofini, Ilaria; Adamo, Carlo
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2012), 45 (8), 1268-1277CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review. Since dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) appeared as a promising inexpensive alternative to the traditional silicon-based solar cells, DSSCs have attracted a considerable amt. of exptl. and theor. interest. In contrast with silicon-based solar cells, DSSCs use different components for the light-harvesting and transport functions, which allow researchers to fine-tune each material and, under ideal conditions, to optimize their overall performance in assembled devices. Because of the variety of elementary components present in these cells and their multiple possible combinations, this task presents exptl. challenges. The photoconversion efficiencies obtained up to this point are still low, despite the significant exptl. efforts spent in their optimization. The development of a low-cost and efficient computational protocol that could qual. (or even quant.) identify the promising semiconductors, dyes, and electrolytes, as well as their assembly, could save substantial exptl. time and resources. The authors describe their computational approach that allows understanding and predicting the different elementary mechanisms involved in DSSC working principles. This computational framework is used to propose an in silico route for the ab initio design of these materials. The presented approach relies on a unique d. functional theory (DFT) based model, which allows for an accurate and balanced treatment of electronic and spectroscopic properties in different phases (such as gas, soln., or interfaces) and avoids or minimizes spurious computational effects. Using this tool, the properties of the isolated components of the DSSC assemblies are reproduced and predicted. The authors accessed the microscopic measurable characteristics of the cells such as the short circuit current (Jsc) or the open circuit voltage (Voc), which define the overall photoconversion efficiency of the cell. The absence of empirical or material-related parameters in the presented approach should allow for its wide application to the optimization of existing devices or the design of new ones.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XlsVaktrs%253D&md5=c836de044d6d9ca0a0b3f91f435e34e5
      open URL
    4. 4
      Heeger, A. J. 25th Anniversary Article: Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Understanding the Mechanism of Operation. Adv. Mater. 2014, 26, 10– 28,  DOI: 10.1002/adma.201304373
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      4
      25th Anniversary Article: Bulk Heterojunction Solar Cells: Understanding the Mechanism of Operation
      Heeger, Alan J.
      Advanced Materials (Weinheim, Germany) (2014), 26 (1), 10-28CODEN: ADVMEW; ISSN:0935-9648. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A review. The status of understanding of the operation of bulk heterojunction solar cells is discussed. Because the carrier photoexcitation recombination lengths are typically 10 nm in these disordered materials, the length scale for self-assembly must be on the order of 10-20 nm. Expts. have verified the existence of the bulk heterojunction nanostructure, but the morphol. remains complex and a limiting factor. Three steps are required for generation of elec. power: (a) absorption of photons from the sun; (b) photoinduced charge sepn. and the generation of mobile carriers; and (c) collection of electrons and holes at opposite electrodes. The ultrafast charge transfer process arises from fundamental quantum uncertainty; mobile carriers are directly generated (electrons in the acceptor domains and holes in the donor domains) by the ultrafast charge transfer (≈70%) with ≈30% generated by exciton diffusion to a charge sepg. heterojunction. Sweep-out of the mobile carriers by the internal field prior to recombination is essential for high performance. Bimol. recombination dominates in materials where the donor and acceptor phases are pure. Impurities degrade performance by introducing Shockley-Read-Hall decay. The review concludes with a summary of the problems to be solved to achieve the predicted power conversion efficiencies of >20% for a single cell.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXhvVykur%252FN&md5=f57101d8c6e984e8760edcd6651e124a
      open URL
    5. 5
      Oregan, B.; Grätzel, M. A Low-Cost, High-Efficiency Solar Cell Based on Dye-Sensitized Colloidal TiO2 Films. Nature 1991, 353, 737– 740,  DOI: 10.1038/353737a0
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      5
      A low-cost, high-efficiency solar cell based on dye-sensitized colloidal titanium dioxide films
      O'Regan, Brian; Graetzel, Michael
      Nature (London, United Kingdom) (1991), 353 (6346), 737-40CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836.
      A photoelectrochem. cell was fabricated from low- to medium-purity materials through low-cost processes, which exhibits a com. realistic energy-conversion efficiency. The device is based on a 10-μm-thick, optically transparent film of TiO2 particles, coated with a monolayer of a charge-transfer dye to sensitize the film for light harvesting. The device harvests a high proportion of the incident solar energy flux (46%) and shows exceptionally high efficiencies for the conversion of incident photons to elec. current (>80%). The overall light-to-elec. energy conversion yield is 7.1-8.9% in simulated solar light and 12% in diffuse daylight. The c.d. >12 mA/cm2 and exceptional stability (sustaining ≥5 million turnover without decompn.), and low cost, make practical applications feasible.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK38XoslOn&md5=02ea66126c0eea94a36e942139157b0f
      open URL

      Bach, U.; Lupo, D.; Comte, P.; Moser, J. E.; Weissortel, F.; Salbeck, J.; Spreitzer, H.; Grätzel, M. Solid-State Dye-Sensitized Mesoporous TiO2 Solar Cells with High Photon-to-Electron Conversion Efficiencies. Nature 1998, 395, 583– 585,  DOI: 10.1038/26936
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      6
      Solid-state dye-sensitized mesoporous TiO2 solar cells with high photon-to-electron conversion efficiencies
      Bach, U.; Lupo, D.; Comte, P.; Moser, J. E.; Weissortel, F.; Salbeck, J.; Spreitzer, H.; Gratzel, M.
      Nature (London) (1998), 395 (6702), 583-585CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Macmillan Magazines)
      Solar cells based on dye-sensitized mesoporous films of TiO2 are low-cost alternatives to conventional solid-state devices. Impressive solar-to-elec. energy conversion efficiencies have been achieved with such films when used in conjunction with liq. electrolytes. Practical advantages may be gained by the replacement of the liq. electrolyte with a solid charge-transport material. Inorg. p-type semiconductors and org. materials have been tested in this regard, but in all cases the incident monochromatic photon-to-electron conversion efficiency remained low. Here we describe a dye-sensitized heterojunction of TiO2 with the amorphous org. hole-transport material 2,2',7,7'-tetrakis(N,N-di-p-methoxyphenyl-amine)9,9'-spirobifluorene (OMeTAD). Photoinduced charge-carrier generation at the heterojunction is very efficient. A solar cell based on OMeTAD converts photons to elec. current with a high yield of 33%.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK1cXms1akur8%253D&md5=c3ae45087da78d6d5b7957b32900bc33
      open URL

      Grätzel, M. Solar Energy Conversion by Dye-Sensitized Photovoltaic Cells. Inorg. Chem. 2005, 44, 6841– 6851,  DOI: 10.1021/ic0508371
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      7
      Solar energy conversion by dye-sensitized photovoltaic cells
      Gratzel Michael
      Inorganic chemistry (2005), 44 (20), 6841-51 ISSN:0020-1669.
      The quality of human life depends to a large degree on the availability of energy. This is threatened unless renewable energy resources can be developed in the near future. Chemistry is expected to make important contributions to identify environmentally friendly solutions of the energy problem. One attractive strategy discussed in this Forum Article is the development of solar cells that are based on the sensitization of mesoscopic oxide films by dyes or quantum dots. These systems have already reached conversion efficiencies exceeding 11%. The underlying fundamental processes of light harvesting by the sensitizer, heterogeneous electron transfer from the electronically excited chromophore into the conduction band of the semiconductor oxide, and percolative migration of the injected electrons through the mesoporous film to the collector electrode will be described below in detail. A number of research topics will also be discussed, and the examples for the first outdoor application of such solar cells will be provided.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BD2MrhtVClug%253D%253D&md5=45cca72678271ada2f6af98c578c8cf5
      open URL

      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      8
      Molecular Photovoltaics
      Hagfeldt, Anders; Graetzel, Michael
      Accounts of Chemical Research (2000), 33 (5), 269-277CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
      A review with 49 refs. The dye-sensitized nanocryst. injection solar cell employs transition metal complexes for spectral sensitization of mesoporous TiO2 films together with suitable redox electrolytes or amorphous org. hole conductors. Light harvesting occurs efficiently over the whole visible and near-IR range due to the very large internal surface area of the films. Judicious mol. engineering allows the photoinduced charge sepn. to occur quant. within a few femtoseconds. The certified overall power conversion efficiency of the new solar cell for AM 1.5 solar radiation stands presently at 10.4%.

      Dye-sensitized solar cells with 13% efficiency achieved through the molecular engineering of porphyrin sensitizers
      Mathew, Simon; Yella, Aswani; Gao, Peng; Humphry-Baker, Robin; Curchod, Basile F. E.; Ashari-Astani, Negar; Tavernelli, Ivano; Rothlisberger, Ursula; Nazeeruddin, Md. Khaja; Graetzel, Michael
      Nature Chemistry (2014), 6 (3), 242-247CODEN: NCAHBB; ISSN:1755-4330. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Dye-sensitized solar cells have gained widespread attention in recent years because of their low prodn. costs, ease of fabrication and tunable optical properties, such as color and transparency. Here, the authors report a molecularly engineered porphyrin dye, coded SM315, which features the prototypical structure of a donor-π-bridge-acceptor and both maximizes electrolyte compatibility and improves light-harvesting properties. Linear-response, time-dependent d. functional theory was used to study the perturbations in the electronic structure that lead to improved light harvesting. Using SM315 with the Co(II/III) redox shuttle resulted in dye-sensitized solar cells that exhibit a high open-circuit voltage VOC of 0.91 V, short-circuit c.d. JSC of 18.1 mA cm-2, fill factor of 0.78 and a power conversion efficiency of 13%.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Yella, A.; Mai, C.-L.; Zakeeruddin, S. M.; Chang, S.-N.; Hsieh, C.-H.; Yeh, C.-Y.; Graätzel, M.       10
      Molecular engineering of push-pull porphyrin dyes for highly efficient dye-sensitized solar cells: the role of benzene spacers
      Yella, Aswani; Mai, Chi-Lun; Zakeeruddin, Shaik M.; Chang, Shu-Nung; Hsieh, Chi-Hung; Yeh, Chen-Yu; Graetzel, Michael
      Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2014), 53 (11), 2973-2977CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Porphyrins have drawn much attention as sensitizers owing to the large absorption coeffs. of their Soret and Q bands in the visible region. In a donor and acceptor zinc porphyrin we applied a new strategy of introducing 2,1,3-benzothiadiazole (BTD) as a π-conjugated linker between the anchoring group and the porphyrin chromophore to broaden the absorption spectra to fill the valley between the Soret and Q bands. With this novel approach, we obsd. 12.75 % power-conversion efficiency under simulated one-sun illumination (AM1.5G, 100 mW cm-2). In this study, we showed the importance of introducing the Ph group as a spacer between the BTD and the zinc porphyrin in achieving high power-conversion efficiencies. Time-resolved fluorescence, transient-photocurrent-decay, and transient-photovoltage-decay measurements were employed to det. the electron-injection dynamics and the lifetime of the photogenerated charge carriers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Yella, A.; Lee, H.-W.; Tsao, H. N.; Yi, C.; Chandiran, A. K.; Nazeeruddin, M. K.; Diau, E. W.-G.; Yeh, C.-Y.; Zakeeruddin, S. M.; Grätzel, M.       Porphyrin-Sensitized Solar Cells with Cobalt (II/III)-Based Redox Electrolyte Exceed 12% Efficiency
      Yella, Aswani; Lee, Hsuan-Wei; Tsao, Hoi Nok; Yi, Chenyi; Chandiran, Aravind Kumar; Nazeeruddin, Md. Khaja; Diau, Eric Wei-Guang; Yeh, Chen-Yu; Zakeeruddin, Shaik M.; Graetzel, Michael
      Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2011), 334 (6056), 629-634CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
      The iodide/triiodide redox shuttle has limited the efficiencies accessible in dye-sensitized solar cells. Here, the authors report mesoscopic solar cells that incorporate a Co(II/III)tris(bipyridyl)-based redox electrolyte in conjunction with a custom synthesized donor-π-bridge-acceptor zinc porphyrin dye as sensitizer (designated YD2-o-C8). The specific mol. design of YD2-o-C8 greatly retards the rate of interfacial back electron transfer from the conduction band of the nanocryst. titanium dioxide film to the oxidized cobalt mediator, which enables attainment of strikingly high photovoltages approaching 1 V. Because the YD2-o-C8 porphyrin harvests sunlight across the visible spectrum, large photocurrents are generated. Cosensitization of YD2-o-C8 with another org. dye further enhances the performance of the device, leading to a measured power conversion efficiency of 12.3% under simulated air mass 1.5 global sunlight.

      New Triphenylamine-Based Dyes for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Xu, Wei; Peng, Bo; Chen, Jun; Liang, Mao; Cai, Fengshi
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2008), 112 (3), 874-880CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      New conjugated metal-free org. dyes (TC1, TC2, TC3, and TC4) comprising triphenylamine (TPA) moieties as the electron donor and cyanoacetic acid moieties as the electron acceptor/anchoring groups were designed at the mol. level and developed for the use in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSCs). Quantum chem. calcns. were performed to gain insight into structural, electronic, and optical properties of the as-synthesized sensitizers. The time-dependent d. functional theory calcns. allowed assignment of the exptl. spectroscopic data. The photovoltaic performance of the DSCs with the as-synthesized dyes can be improved by enhancing the electron-donor ability and extending the π-conjugated bridge of the dyes. In particular, the DSCs based on 2-cyano-5-(4-(phenyl(4-vinylphenyl)amino)phenyl) penta-2,4-dienoic acid dye (TC4) showed an open circuit voltage of 652 mV, a short circuit photocurrent d. of 11.5 mA cm-2, and a fill factor of 0.64, corresponding to an overall light to electricity conversion efficiency of 4.82% under AM 1.5 irradn. (100 mW cm-2). This result reveals that efficient electron injection from the excited sensitizer to the conduction band of titania film occurs, owing to the more delocalizing electrons of the bridge and donor part of the dyes.

      Molecular engineering and theoretical investigation of organic sensitizers based on indoline dyes for quasi-solid state dye-sensitized solar cells
      Liu, Bo; Wu, Wenjun; Li, Xiaoyan; Li, Lei; Guo, Shaofu; Wei, Xiaoru; Zhu, Weihong; Liu, Qingbin
      Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics (2011), 13 (19), 8985-8992CODEN: PPCPFQ; ISSN:1463-9076. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Novel indoline dyes with structural modification of π-linker group in the D-π-A system were synthesized and fully characterized. Mol. engineering through expanding the π-linker segment was performed. The ground and excited state properties of the dyes were studied by means of d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT). Larger π-conjugation linkers would lead to broader spectral response and higher molar extinction coeff. but would decrease dye-loaded amt. on TiO2 electrode and LUMO level. While applied in DSSCs, the variation trends in short-circuit c.d. (Jsc) and open-circuit voltage (Voc) were obsd. to be opposite to each other. The internal reasons were studied by exptl. data and theor. calcns. in detail. Notably, I-2 showed comparable photocurrent values with liq. and quasi-solid state electrolyte, which suggested through mol. engineering of org. sensitizers the dilemma between optical absorption and charge diffusion lengths can be balanced well. Through studies of photophys., electrochem., and theor. calcn. results, the internal relations between chem. structure and efficiency were revealed, which serve to enhance our knowledge regarding design and optimization of new sensitizers for quasi-solid state DSSCs, providing a powerful strategy for prediction of photovoltaic performances.

      14
      Insight into D-A-π-A Structured Sensitizers: A Promising Route to Highly Efficient and Stable Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Wu, Yongzhen; Zhu, Wei-Hong; Zakeeruddin, Shaik M.; Gratzel, Michael
      ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces (2015), 7 (18), 9307-9318CODEN: AAMICK; ISSN:1944-8244. (American Chemical Society)
      The dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC) is one of the most promising photovoltaic technologies with potential of low cost, light wt., and good flexibility. The practical application of DSSCs requires further improvement in power conversion efficiency and long-term stability. Recently, significant progress has been witnessed in DSSC research owing to the novel concept of the D-A-π-A motif for the mol. engineering of org. photosensitizers. New org. and porphyrin dyes based on the D-A-π-A motif can not only enhance photovoltaic performance, but also improve durability in DSSC applications. This spotlight on applications highlights recent advances in the D-A-π-A-based photosensitizers, specifically focusing on the mechanism of efficiency and stability enhancements. Also, insight is found into the addnl. acceptor as well as the trade-off of long wavelength response. The basic principles are involved in mol. engineering of efficient D-A-π-A sensitizers, providing a clear road map showing how to modulate the energy bands, rationally extending the response wavelength, and optimizing photovoltaic efficiency step by step.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      A benzothiadiazole-cyclopentadithiophene bridged D-A-π-A sensitizer with enhanced light absorption for high efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells
      Wang, Xingzhu; Yang, Jing; Yu, Hao; Li, Feng; Fan, Li; Sun, Wen; Liu, Yeru; Koh, Zhen Yu; Pan, Jiahong; Yim, Wai-Leung; Yan, Lei; Wang, Qing
      Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2014), 50 (30), 3965-3968CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      The authors demonstrate an efficient D-A-π-A sensitizer with a benzothiadiazole-cyclopentadithiophene moiety as the spacer in a triphenylamine org. dye for dye-sensitized solar cells. The dye has a broad visible light absorption range up to 800 nm. A power conversion efficiency >9% was achieved using a [Co(bpy)3]2+/3+-based electrolyte.

      Gao, Y.; Li, X.; Hu, Y.; Fan, Y.; Yuan, J.; Robertson, N.; Hua, J.; Marder, S. R. Effect of an Auxiliary Acceptor on D–A−π–A Sensitizers for Highly Efficient and Stable Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. J. Mater. Chem. A 2016, 4, 12865– 12877,  DOI: 10.1039/C6TA05588E
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      16
      Effect of an auxiliary acceptor on D-A-π-A sensitizers for highly efficient and stable dye-sensitized solar cells
      Gao, Yuting; Li, Xing; Hu, Yue; Fan, Yeli; Yuan, Jianyong; Robertson, Neil; Hua, Jianli; Marder, Seth R.
      Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability (2016), 4 (33), 12865-12877CODEN: JMCAET; ISSN:2050-7496. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      As one of the promising photovoltaic technologies, high performance metal-free dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have been explored due to the fact that they can be potentially produced using low-cost materials, their color can be tuned and they exhibit reasonable stability. Here three new org. donor-acceptor-π-acceptor (D-A-π-A) sensitizers (B-87, Q-85 and Q-93), contg. benzothiadiazole and two new modified pyrido[3,4-b]pyrazines as the auxiliary acceptor, have been synthesized and employed in DSSCs. Among the three dyes, B-87 and Q-85 showed good photovoltaic performance with power conversion efficiencies (PCE) up to 10.2% and 10.0%, resp., which contribute to the few examples of DSSCs synthesized using pure org. dyes with an iodine electrolyte to exceed the 10% efficiency barrier. It is noteworthy that an initial PCE of 7.16% has been achieved for B-87 based DSSCs with an ionic liq. electrolyte, which retained 95% of the initial efficiency after continuous light soaking for 1000 h at 60 °C, thus demonstrating outstanding stability. The mol. design strategy provides an effective approach to modulate the energy of the absorption bands as well as modify the optoelectronic and phys. properties of the org. sensitizers to achieve highly efficient and stable sensitizers.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtF2msb7O&md5=0dd2b193e6a0ea06ae5ce4eb0e558680
      open URL
    17. 17
      Abe, M.; Adam, W.; Heidenfelder, T.; Nau, W. M.; Zhang, X. Intramolecular and Intermolecular Reactivity of Localized Singlet Diradicals: The Exceedingly Long-Lived 2,2-diethoxy-1,3-diphenylcyclopentane-1,3-diyl. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2000, 122, 2019– 2026,  DOI: 10.1021/ja992507j
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      17
      Intramolecular and Intermolecular Reactivity of Localized Singlet Diradicals: The Exceedingly Long-Lived 2,2-Diethoxy-1,3-diphenylcyclopentane-1,3-diyl
      Abe, Manabu; Adam, Waldemar; Heidenfelder, Thomas; Nau, Werner M.; Zhang, Xiangyang
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2000), 122 (9), 2019-2026CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The direct and benzophenone-sensitized photodenitrogenation of the diethoxy-substituted diazene I in nonprotic solvents, e.g. n-hexane, benzene, and acetonitrile, afforded exclusively the housane II through the intermediary 2,2-diethoxy-1,3-diphenylcyclopentane-1,3-diyl diradical III. Alternatively, in the presence of methanol, the formation of the adduct IV competed through trapping of the allylic cation V. The intervention of the intermediates was corroborated by laser-flash photolysis expts. of the diazene I. The diradical intermediate was characterized by its strong transient absorption at 545 nm, which decayed with a first-order lifetime in the microsecond range. The diradical lifetimes increased in the order n-hexane (0.52 μs), benzene (0.88 μs), acetonitrile (1.01 μs), and chloroform (3.73 μs). The singlet ground state of the 2,2-diethoxy-substituted 1,3-diradical III is suggested by the absence of EPR signals at low temp., the lack of quenching by mol. oxygen, and the calcd. (UB3LYP/6-31G*) singlet preference of ca. 4 kcal mol-1 for 2,2-dihydroxy-1,3-diphenyl-1,3-cyclopentanediyl as a model. Trapping of the 1,3-diradical III by external additives, e.g., olefins, dienes, and TEMPO, was not obsd. In protic solvents, a decrease of the diradical lifetimes with increasing acidity was noted, e.g., the lifetime in acetic acid dropped to 70 ns. Moreover, a concomitant growth of an addnl. transient at 470 nm was found in acidic solvents, which was assigned to the allylic cation V. The factors governing the intramol. and intermol. chem. reactivity of the localized singlet diradical III are discussed.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3cXhtFWrtr0%253D&md5=8307e2be2d5fa49ca50449d7a4f29e43
      open URL
    18. 18
      Adam, W.; Borden, W. T.; Burda, C.; Foster, H.; Heidenfelder, T.; Heubes, M.; Hrovat, D. A.; Kita, F.; Lewis, S. B.; Scheutzow, D. Transient Spectroscopy of a Derivative of 2,2-Difluoro-1,3-Diphenylcyclopentane-1,3-Diyl – A Persistent Localized Singlet 1,3-Diradical. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1998, 120, 593– 594,  DOI: 10.1021/ja972977i
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Transient spectroscopy of a derivative of 2,2-difluoro-1,3-diphenylcyclopentane-1,3-diyl-a remarkably persistent localized singlet 1,3-diradical
      Adam, Waldemar; Borden, Weston Thatcher; Burda, Clemens; Foster, Heather; Heidenfelder, Thomas; Heubes, Markus; Hrovat, David A.; Kita, Fumio; Lewis, Scott B.; Scheutzow, Dieter; Wirz, Jakob
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (1998), 120 (3), 593-594CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      3,3-Difluoro-2,4-diphenylbicyclo[3.3.0]octane-2,4-diyl (I) was generated by photolysis of an azo precursor and characterized by UV spectroscopy, both in soln. and in matrix isolation. Depending on the solvent polarity, diradical I either cyclizes to a housane deriv., or loses F- ion to give an allylic cation from which a cyclopentene is formed. Evidence is presented that I is an unusually long-lived singlet diradical, which disappears with Ea = 7.8 ± 0.5 kcal/mol in cyclohexane soln. and is stable for about a day in glasses at 77 K.

      Sauvage, F.; Chen, D.; Comte, P.; Huang, F.; Heiniger, L.-P.; Cheng, Y.-B.; Caruso, R. A.; Grätzel, M. Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells Employing a Single Film of Mesoporous TiO2 Beads Achieve Power Conversion Efficiencies Over 10%. ACS Nano 2010, 4, 4420– 4425,  DOI: 10.1021/nn1010396
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      19
      Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells Employing a Single Film of Mesoporous TiO2 Beads Achieve Power Conversion Efficiencies Over 10%
      Sauvage, Frederic; Chen, Dehong; Comte, Pascal; Huang, Fuzhi; Heiniger, Leo-Philipp; Cheng, Yi-Bing; Caruso, Rachel A.; Graetzel, Michael
      ACS Nano (2010), 4 (8), 4420-4425CODEN: ANCAC3; ISSN:1936-0851. (American Chemical Society)
      Dye-sensitized solar cells employing mesoporous TiO2 beads have demonstrated longer electron diffusion lengths and extended electron lifetimes over Degussa P25 titania electrodes due to the well interconnected, densely packed nanocryst. TiO2 particles inside the beads. Careful selection of the dye to match the dye photon absorption characteristics with the light scattering properties of the beads have improved the light harvesting and conversion efficiency of the bead electrode in the dye-sensitized solar cell. This has resulted in a solar-to-elec. power conversion efficiency of >10% (10.6% for Ru(II)-based dye C101 and 10.7% using C106) using a single screen-printed titania layer cell construction (i.e., without an addnl. scattering layer).

      He, J.; Wu, W.; Hua, J.; Jiang, Y.; Qu, S.; Li, J.; Long, Y.; Tian, H. Bithiazole-Bridged Dyes for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells with High Open Circuit Voltage Performance. J. Mater. Chem. 2011, 21, 6054,  DOI: 10.1039/c0jm03811c
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Bithiazole-bridged dyes for dye-sensitized solar cells with high open circuit voltage performance
      He, Jinxiang; Wu, Wenjun; Hua, Jianli; Jiang, Yihua; Qu, Sanyin; Li, Jing; Long, Yitao; Tian, He
      Journal of Materials Chemistry (2011), 21 (16), 6054-6062CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Five new metal-free org. dyes (T1-T5) contg. bithiazole moieties were synthesized and used for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). Their absorption spectra, electrochem. and photovoltaic properties were fully characterized. Electrochem. measurement data indicate that the tuning of the HOMO and LUMO energy levels can be conveniently accomplished by alternating the donor moiety. All of these dyes performed as sensitizers for the DSSC test, and the photovoltaic performance data of these bithiazole-bridged dyes showed higher open circuit voltages (745-810 mV). Among the 5 dyes, T1 showed the best photovoltaic performance of a max. monochromatic incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of 83.8%, a short-circuit photocurrent d. (Jsc) of 11.78 mA cm-2, an open-circuit photovoltage (Voc) of 810 mV, and a fill factor (ff) of 0.60, corresponding to an overall conversion efficiency of 5.73% under std. global AM 1.5 solar light condition, which reached 93% with respect to that of an N719-based device fabricated under similar conditions. The metal-free dyes based on bithiazole π-conjugation are promising candidates for improvement of the performance of DSSCs.

      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3MXktlyju78%253D&md5=7b84f78d2cf9fe72d72d825e1370b6a5

      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Organic D-A-π-A Solar Cell Sensitizers with Improved Stability and Spectral Response
      Zhu, Weihong; Wu, Yongzhen; Wang, Shutao; Li, Wenqin; Li, Xin; Chen, Jian; Wang, Zhong-sheng; Tian, He
      Advanced Functional Materials (2011), 21 (4), 756-763CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      A novel concept D-A-π-A org. sensitizer instead of traditional D-π-A ones is proposed. The incorporated low band gap, strong electron-withdrawing unit of benzothiadiazole shows several favorable characteristics in the areas of light-harvesting and efficiency of (i) optimized energy levels, resulting in a large responsive range of wavelengths into NIR region; (ii) a very small blue-shift in the absorption peak on thin TiO2 films with respect to that in soln.; (iii) an improvement in the electron distribution of the donor unit to distinctly increase the photo-stability of synthetic intermediates and final sensitizers. The stability and spectral response of indoline dye-based DSSCs are improved by the strong electron-withdrawing benzothiadizole unit in the conjugation bridge. The incident-photon-conversion efficiency of WS-2 reaches nearly 850 nm with a power conversion efficiency ≤ 8.7% in liq. electrolyte and 6.6% in ionic-liq. electrolyte.

      Roy, J. K.; Kar, S.; Leszczynski, J. Electronic Structure and Optical Properties of Designed Photo-Efficient Indoline-Based Dye-Sensitizers with D–A−π–A Framework. J. Phys. Chem. C 2019, 123, 3309– 3320,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.8b10708
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      22
      Electronic Structure and Optical Properties of Designed Photo-Efficient Indoline-Based Dye-Sensitizers with D-A-π-A Framework
      Roy, Juganta K.; Kar, Supratik; Leszczynski, Jerzy
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2019), 123 (6), 3309-3320CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Seven D-A-π-A-based indoline (IND) dyes that were designed via quant.-structure-property relationship modeling have been comprehensively investigated using computational approaches to evaluate their prospect of application in future dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). An array of optoelectronic properties of the isolated dye and dyes adsorbed on a TiO2 cluster that simulates the semiconductor were explored by d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT methods. Light absorption spectra, vertical dipole moment, shift of the conduction band of semiconductor, excited state lifetime, driving force of electron injection, photostability of the excited state, and exciton binding energy were computed. Our study showed that the presence of an internal acceptor such as pyrido[3,4-b]pyrazine (pyrazine) would influence greater the open circuit voltage (VOC), compared to the benzothiadiazole moiety. Considering the balance between the VOC and JSC (short circuit current) along with the all calcd. characteristics, the IND3, IND5, and IND10 are the most suited among the designed dyes to be used as potential candidates for the photo-efficient DSSCs. The present study provides the results of rational mol. design followed by exploration of photophys. properties to be used as a valuable ref. for the synthesis of photo-efficient dyes for DSSCs.

      D-A-π-A System: Light Harvesting, Charge Transfer, and Molecular Designing
      Li, Yuanzuo; Xu, Beibei; Song, Peng; Ma, Fengcai; Sun, Mengtao
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2017), 121 (23), 12546-12561CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Three org. dyes (XY1, XY2, and XY3), synthesized by inserting a thiophene heterocycle and shifting the position of benzothiadiazole (BTZ) auxiliary acceptor on the cyclopentadithiophene(CPDT) π-bridge, are theor. investigated using d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) for their potential applications in solar cells. The photoelec. parameters (short-circuit current, open circuit voltage, conversion efficiency) are evaluated by the following factors: energy levels and the orbital compns., the absorption spectra, NBO anal. from S0 to S1, the qual. descriptions of DCT, Δr, S, and ΔQ for intramol. charge transfer (ICT) processing, the adsorption energy (Eads), and the excited lifetime (t), the shift of CB and vertical dipole moment (μnormal), the electron injection lifetime (τ), the Marcus rate of inner-path recombination, the simulation of outer-path recombination dye···I2 and dye regeneration [dye+•I-], etc. The Eads, the excited lifetime (t) and the electron injection lifetime (τ) explain the order of exptl. JSC, and the trend of Voc is interpreted by the calcns. on the ΔECB, μnormal, the Marcus rate and the dye···I2 mode. Among three mols., XY2 possesses the significance advantage in ICT mechanism and dye regeneration ability based on anal. of qual. descriptions and two-step regeneration mechanism. Moreover, 12 dyes are designed by the substitution of π-bridge of XY2, which provide a strategy to improve the abilities of absorption and electron injection as well as photoelec. properties on the comparison of XY2.

      Pei, K.; Wu, Y.; Wu, W.; Zhang, Q.; Chen, B.; Tian, H.; Zhu, W. Constructing Organic D–A−π–A-Featured Sensitizers with a Quinoxaline Unit for High-Efficiency Solar Cells: The Effect of an Auxiliary Acceptor on the Absorption and the Energy Level Alignment.       24
      Constructing Organic D-A-π-A-Featured Sensitizers with a Quinoxaline Unit for High-Efficiency Solar Cells: The Effect of an Auxiliary Acceptor on the Absorption and the Energy Level Alignment
      Pei, Kai; Wu, Yongzhen; Wu, Wenjun; Zhang, Qiong; Chen, Baoqin; Tian, He; Zhu, Weihong
      Chemistry - A European Journal (2012), 18 (26), 8190-8200, S8190/1-S8190/11CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Four org. D-A-π-A-featured sensitizers (TQ1, TQ2, IQ1, and IQ2) have been studied for high-efficiency dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). The authors employed an indoline or a triphenylamine unit as the donor, cyanoacetic acid as the acceptor/anchor, and a thiophene moiety as the conjugation bridge. Addnl., an electron-withdrawing quinoxaline unit was incorporated between the donor and the π-conjugation unit. These sensitizers show an addnl. absorption band covering the broad visible range in soln. The contribution from the incorporated quinoxaline was studied theor. by using DFT and time-dependent DFT. The incorporated low-band-gap quinoxaline unit as an auxiliary acceptor has several merits, such as decreasing the band gap, optimizing the energy levels, and realizing a facile structural modification on several positions in the quinoxaline unit. As demonstrated, the obsd. addnl. absorption band is favorable to the photon-to-electron conversion because it corresponds to the efficient electron transitions to the LUMO orbital. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy (EIS) Bode plots reveal that the replacement of a methoxy group with an octyloxy group can increase the injection electron lifetime by a factor of 2.4. IQ2 and TQ2 can perform well without any co-adsorbent, successfully suppress the charge recombination from TiO2 conduction band to I3- in the electrolyte, and enhance the electron lifetime, resulting in a decreased dark current and enhanced open circuit voltage (Voc) values. By using a liq. electrolyte, DSSCs based on dye IQ2 exhibited a broad incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) action spectrum and high efficiency (η=8.50 %) with a short circuit c.d. (Jsc) of 15.65 mA cm-2, a Voc value of 776 mV, a fill factor (FF) of 0.70 under AM 1.5 illumination (100 mW cm-2). Also, the overall efficiency remained at 97% of the initial value after 1000 h of visible-light soaking.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC38XntlSkt7Y%253D&md5=293baffa0ec91cceccdfa63da3fa2010

      Ying, W.; Yang, J.; Wielopolski, M.; Moehl, T.; Moser, J.-E.; Comte, P.; Hua, J. L.; Zakeeruddin, S. M.; Tian, H.; Grätzel, M. New Pyrido [3,4-B] Pyrazine-Based Sensitizers for Efficient and Stable Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. Chem. Sci. 2014, 5, 206– 214,  DOI: 10.1039/C3SC51844B
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar

      New pyrido[3,4-b]pyrazine-based sensitizers for efficient and stable dye-sensitized solar cells
      Ying, Weijiang; Yang, Jiabao; Wielopolski, Mateusz; Moehl, Thomas; Moser, Jacques-E.; Comte, Pascal; Hua, Jianli; Zakeeruddin, Shaik M.; Tian, He; Graetzel, Michael
      Chemical Science (2014), 5 (1), 206-214CODEN: CSHCCN; ISSN:2041-6520. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A series of new pyrido[3,4-b]pyrazine-based org. sensitizers (PP-I and APP-I-IV) contg. different donors and π-spacers have been synthesized and employed in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). The absorption spectra properties of dyes are analyzed by d. functional theory (DFT). The calcd. results in combination with the expts. suggest that the absorption characteristics and excited state features will mainly be dominated by charge transfer transitions from the HOMO (HOMO) to the LUMO (LUMO) and to higher LUMO orbitals. Furthermore, attaching the octyloxy groups significantly extends the π-conjugation of the donor in APP-IV, which raises the HOMO energy and facilitates its oxidn. As a consequence, APP-IV exhibits the lowest HOMO-LUMO energy gap among all dyes, which, in turn, corresponds well with the red shift of the absorption spectra. Transient photovoltage and photocurrent decay expts. as well as electrochem. impedance spectroscopy indicate that the electron lifetime and charge recombination resistance are increased due to the introduction of octyloxy chains on the donor unit, resulting in the high photovoltage based on APP-IV. It was found that APP-IV based DSSCs with liq. electrolyte display the highest power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 7.12%. Importantly, a PCE of 6.20% has been achieved for APP-IV based DSSCs with ionic-liq. electrolytes and retained 97% of the initial value after continuous light soaking for 1000 h at 60 °C. This renders these pyrido[3,4-b]pyrazine-based sensitizers quite promising candidates for highly efficient and stable DSSCs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Wu, Y.; Zhu, W. Organic Sensitizers From D−π–A to D–A−π–A: Effect of the Internal Electron-Withdrawing Units on Molecular Absorption, Energy Levels and Photovoltaic Performances. Chem. Soc. Rev. 2013, 42, 2039– 2058,  DOI: 10.1039/C2CS35346F
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      26
      Organic sensitizers from D-π-A to D-A-π-A: effect of the internal electron-withdrawing units on molecular absorption, energy levels and photovoltaic performances
      Wu, Yongzhen; Zhu, Weihong
      Chemical Society Reviews (2013), 42 (5), 2039-2058CODEN: CSRVBR; ISSN:0306-0012. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      A review. The high performance and low cost of dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs) have drawn great interest from both academic and industrial circles. The research on exploring novel efficient sensitizers, esp. on inexpensive metal-free pure org. dyes, has never been suspended. The donor-π bridge-acceptor (D-π-A) configuration is mainstream in the design of org. sensitizers due to its convenient modulation of the intramol. charge-transfer nature. Recently, it has been found that incorporation of addnl. electron-withdrawing units (such as benzothiadiazole, benzotriazole, quinoxaline, phthalimide, diketopyrrolopyrrole, thienopyrazine, thiazole, triazine, cyanovinyl, cyano- and fluoro-substituted phenyl) into the π bridge as internal acceptors, termed the D-A-π-A configuration, displays several advantages such as tuning of the mol. energy levels, red-shift of the charge-transfer absorption band, and distinct improvement of photovoltaic performance and stability. We apply the D-A-π-A concept broadly to the org. sensitizers contg. addnl. electron-withdrawing units between electron donors and acceptors. This review is projected to summarize the category of pure org. sensitizers on the basis of the D-A-π-A feature. By comparing the structure-property relationship of typical photovoltaic D-A-π-A dyes, the important guidelines in the design of such materials are highlighted.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC3sXit1Grsbg%253D&md5=de18c04c7030279da76f0319c859ebdd
      open URL

      New carbazole-based dyes with asymmetric butterfly structure for dye-sensitized solar cells: Design and properties studies
      Sun, Kenan; Ma, Yuan; Zhang, Weiyi; Wen, Yaping; Wang, Li; Zhang, Jinglai
      Dyes and Pigments (2017), 139 (), 148-156CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      A series of carbazole-based org. dyes with asym. butterfly structure are designed and their efficiency is theor. estd. In the left "wing", benzene and thiophene are employed as the π group. For resp. left "wing", three different right "wings" are constructed. The influence of nature and no. of different π group on the efficiency is investigated. On the basis of the isolated dyes, the short-circuit c.d. (Jsc), open-circuit voltage (Voc), and reorganization energy (λtotal) are detd. to evaluate the efficiency of the solar cell. Moreover, the structure of the dye adsorbed on the (TiO2)38 cluster is optimized by the first-principle. The adsorption energy and the d. of states (DOS) are calcd. to further est. the efficiency. Combining all factors, the employment of two Ph groups as π group of the right "wing" is favorable to improve the efficiency.

      A Metal-Free N-Annulated Thienocyclopentaperylene Dye: Power Conversion Efficiency of 12 % for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Yao, Zhaoyang; Zhang, Min; Li, Renzhi; Yang, Lin; Qiao, Yongna; Wang, Peng

      Reported are two highly efficient metal-free perylene dyes featuring N-annulated thienobenzoperylene (NTBP) and N-annulated thienocyclopentaperylene (NTCP), which are coplanar polycyclic arom. hydrocarbons. Without the use of any coadsorbate, the metal-free org. dye derived from the NTCP segment was used for a dye-sensitized solar cell which attained a power conversion efficiency of 12 % under an irradiance of 100 mW cm-2, simulated air mass global (AM1.5G) sunlight.

      Jiao, Y.; Zhang, F.; Gratzel, M.; Meng, S. Structure–Property Relations in All-Organic Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. Adv. Funct. Mater. 2013, 23, 424– 429,  DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201201831

      29
      Structure-Property Relations in All-Organic Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Jiao, Yang; Zhang, Fan; Graetzel, Michael; Meng, Sheng
      Advanced Functional Materials (2013), 23 (4), 424-429CODEN: AFMDC6; ISSN:1616-301X. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
      Structure-property relations in all-org. dye solar cells were studied by 1st-principles mol. dynamics and real-time time-dependent d. functional theory simulations followed by exptl. confirmation. An important structural feature at the interface, Ti-N anchoring, for a broad group of all-org. dyes on TiO2 is inferred from energetics, vibrational recognition, and electronic data. This fact is contrary to the usual assumption; however, it optimizes electronic level alignment and photoelectron injection dynamics, greatly contributing to the obsd. efficiency improvement in all-org. cyanoacrylate dye sensitized solar cells.

      Metal-free organic sensitizers with a sterically hindered thiophene unit for efficient dye-sensitized solar cells
      Kozma, Erika; Concina, Isabella; Braga, Antonio; Borgese, Laura; Depero, Laura E.; Vomiero, Alberto; Sberveglieri, Giorgio; Catellani, Marinella
      Journal of Materials Chemistry (2011), 21 (36), 13785-13788CODEN: JMACEP; ISSN:0959-9428. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
      Two new org. sensitizers for dye solar cells contg. a sterically hindered moiety have been synthesized. The introduction of a 3,4-dibutylthiophene ring into D-π-A dyes reduces the sensitizer aggregation and allows the prepn. of solar cells with power conversion efficiency of 7.17% and 6.27% without the use of co-adsorbent agents.

      Qu, S. Y.; Wu, W. J.; Hua, J. L.; Kong, C.; Long, Y. T.; Tian, H. New Diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) Dyes for Efficient Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. J. Phys. Chem. C 2010, 114, 1343– 1349,  DOI: 10.1021/jp909786k
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      31
      New Diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) Dyes for Efficient Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Qu, Sanyin; Wu, Wenjun; Hua, Jianli; Kong, Cong; Long, Yitao; Tian, He
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2010), 114 (2), 1343-1349CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      Two novel metal-free dyes with a diketopyrrolopyrrole (DPP) core were synthesized for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). The absorption spectra and electrochem. and photovoltaic properties of the two dyes were extensively investigated. Electrochem. measurement data indicate that the tuning of the HOMO and LUMO energy levels can be conveniently accomplished by alternating the π-conjugated systems. Besides, coadsorption of chenodeoxycholic acid (CDCA) can hinder the formation of dye aggregates and might improve electron injection yield and, thus, Jsc. This has also led to a rise in the photovoltage, which is attributed to the decrease of charge recombination. The DSSC based on dye one dye showed better photovoltaic performance: a max. monochromatic incident photon-to-current conversion efficiency (IPCE) of 80%, a short-circuit photocurrent d. (Jsc) of 9.78 mA cm-2, an open-circuit photovoltage (Voc) of 605 mV, and a fill factor (FF) of 0.69, corresponding to an overall conversion efficiency of 4.14% under std. global AM 1.5 solar light condition. This work suggests that the metal-free dyes based on a DPP core are promising candidates for improvement of the performance of DSSCs.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD1MXhsFOisr7O&md5=0f868f5fda79b273e26eba60991928b4
      open URL
    32. 32
      Yum, J.-H.; Baranoff, E.; Kessler, F.; Moehl, T.; Ahmad, S.; Bessho, T.; Marchioro, A.; Ghadiri, E.; Moser, J.-E.; Yi, C. A Cobalt Complex Redox Shuttle for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells with High Open-Circuit Potentials. Nat. Commun. 2012, 3, 631  DOI: 10.1038/ncomms1655
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      32
      A cobalt complex redox shuttle for dye-sensitized solar cells with high open-circuit potentials
      Yum Jun-Ho; Baranoff Etienne; Kessler Florian; Moehl Thomas; Ahmad Shahzada; Bessho Takeru; Marchioro Arianna; Ghadiri Elham; Moser Jacques-E; Yi Chenyi; Nazeeruddin Md K; Gratzel Michael
      Nature communications (2012), 3 (), 631 ISSN:.
      Dye-sensitized solar cells are a promising alternative to traditional inorganic semiconductor-based solar cells. Here we report an open-circuit voltage of over 1,000 mV in mesoscopic dye-sensitized solar cells incorporating a molecularly engineered cobalt complex as redox mediator. Cobalt complexes have negligible absorption in the visible region of the solar spectrum, and their redox properties can be tuned in a controlled fashion by selecting suitable donor/acceptor substituents on the ligand. This approach offers an attractive alternate to the traditional I(3)(-)/I(-) redox shuttle used in dye-sensitized solar cells. A cobalt complex using tridendate ligands [Co(bpy-pz)(2)](3+/2+)(PF(6))(3/2) as redox mediator in combination with a cyclopentadithiophene-bridged donor-acceptor dye (Y123), adsorbed on TiO(2), yielded a power conversion efficiency of over 10% at 100 mW cm(-2). This result indicates that the molecularly engineered cobalt redox shuttle is a legitimate alternative to the commonly used I(3)(-)/I(-) redox shuttle.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A280%3ADC%252BC387ltleqsA%253D%253D&md5=672565c0319f7322d709c2674f6b787e
      open URL

      Yang, J.; Ganesan, P.; Teuscher, J.; Moehl, T.; Kim, Y. J.; Yi, C.; Comte, P.; Pei, K.; Holcombe, T. W.; Nazeeruddin, M. K. Influence of the Donor Size in D−π–A Organic Dyes for DyeSensitized Solar Cells. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2014, 136, 5722– 5730,  DOI: 10.1021/ja500280r
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      33
      Influence of the Donor Size in D-π-A Organic Dyes for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells
      Yang, Jiabao; Ganesan, Paramaguru; Teuscher, Joel; Moehl, Thomas; Kim, Yong Joo; Yi, Chenyi; Comte, Pascal; Pei, Kai; Holcombe, Thomas W.; Nazeeruddin, Mohammad Khaja; Hua, Jianli; Zakeeruddin, Shaik M.; Tian, He; Gratzel, Michael
      Journal of the American Chemical Society (2014), 136 (15), 5722-5730CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
      The authors report 2 new molecularly engineered push-pull dyes, i.e., YA421 and YA422, based on substituted quinoxaline as a π-conjugating linker and bulky-indoline moiety as donor and compared with reported IQ4 dye. Benefitting from increased steric hindrance with the introduction of bis(2,4-dihexyloxy)benzene substitution on the quinoxaline, the electron recombination between redox electrolyte and the TiO2 surface is reduced, esp. in redox electrolyte employing Co(II/III) complexes as redox shuttles. The open circuit photovoltages of IQ4, YA421, and YA422 devices with Co-based electrolyte are higher than those with iodide/triiodide electrolyte by 34, 62, and 135 mV, resp. Also, the cells employing graphene nanoplatelets on top of Au spattered film as a counter electrode (CE) show lower charge-transfer resistance compared to Pt as a CE. Consequently, YA422 devices deliver the best power conversion efficiency due to higher fill factor, reaching 10.65% at AM 1.5 simulated sunlight. Electrochem. impedance spectroscopy and transient absorption spectroscopy anal. were performed to understand the electrolyte influence on the device performances with different counter electrode materials and donor structures of donor-π-acceptor dyes. Laser flash photolysis expts. indicate that even though the dye regeneration of YA422 is slower than that of the other 2 dyes, the slower back electron transfer of YA422 contributes to the higher device performance.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      Sulzer, D.; Yasuda, K. Resonance State Method for Electron Injection in Dye Sensitized Solar Cells. J. Chem. Theory Comput. 2018, 14, 5090– 5104,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jctc.8b00364
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      34
      Resonance State Method for Electron Injection in Dye Sensitized Solar Cells
      Sulzer, David; Yasuda, Koji
      Journal of Chemical Theory and Computation (2018), 14 (10), 5090-5104CODEN: JCTCCE; ISSN:1549-9618. (American Chemical Society)
      Herein, the ab initio method is applied to examine metastable mol. excited states on a solid surface using resonance state theory and Green's function. A formula for the complex energy correction that dets. the decay rate is presented; the CI effect together with major mol.-surface interactions are considered in more detail as compared to previous studies. Furthermore, the lifetimes of the excited states of Ru-terpyridine dyes adsorbed on an anatase surface are calcd., and the effects of the mol. structure and adsorption mode on the electron injection rate are studied. Also, the adsorption structures and relative stabilities of a series of Ru-terpyridine dyes-including the black dye-are reported. An implicit solvation model is necessary to reliably calc. the alignment between the photoabsorption spectrum and the conduction band d. of states, governing the injection rate. Finally, some of the factors that limit the injection ability of dyes are discussed.

      Yang, Z.; Liu, C.; Li, K.; Cole, J. M.; Shao, C.; Cao, D. Rotational Design of Dithienopicenocarbazole-Based Dyes and a Prediction of Their Energy-Conversion Efficiency Characteristics for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells. ACS Appl. Energy Mater. 2018, 1, 1435– 1444,  DOI: 10.1021/acsaem.7b00154
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar

      Rational design of dithienopicenocarbazole-based dyes and a prediction of their energy-conversion efficiency characteristics for dye-sensitized solar cells
      Yang, Zhenqing; Liu, Chunmeng; Li, Kuan; Cole, Jacqueline M.; Shao, Changjin; Cao, Dapeng
      ACS Applied Energy Materials (2018), 1 (4), 1435-1444CODEN: AAEMCQ; ISSN:2574-0962. (American Chemical Society)
      A series of metal-free org. donor-acceptor (D-A) derivs. (ME01-ME06) of the known dye, C281, were designed using first principles calcns., in order to evaluate their potential for applications in dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). Their phys. and electronic properties were all calcd. using d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT). These include mol. properties that are required to assess the feasibility of a dye to function in DSSCs: UV/vis absorption spectra, light-harvesting efficiency (LHE), and driving forces of electron injection (ΔGinj). ME01, ME02 and ME04 are predicted to exhibit broad absorption optical spectra that cover the entire visible range, rendering these three dyes with promising DSSC prospects. Device-relevant calcns. on these three short-listed dyes and the parent dye, C281, were then performed, whereupon the dye mols. were adsorbed onto anatase TiO2 surfaces to form the DSSC working electrode. Assocd. DSSC device characteristics of this dye-TiO2 interfacial structure were detd. These include the light-harvesting efficiency, the no. of injected electrons, the electron-injection lifetime, and the quantum energy alignment of the adsorbed dye mol. to that of its device components. In turn, these calcd. parameters enabled the derivation of the DSSC device performance parameters: short-circuit c.d., JSC, incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency, IPCE, and open-circuit voltage, VOC. Thus, the authors demonstrate a systematic ab initio approach to screen rationally designed D-A dyes with respect to their potential applicability in high-performance DSSC devices.

      Wen, Y.; Yang, H.; Zheng, D.; Sun, K.; Wang, L.; Zhang, J. First-principles and Molecular Dynamics on A-D(π)-A Type Sensitizers for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: Effects of Various Anchoring Groups on Electronic Coupling and Dye-Aggregation. J. Phys. Chem. C 2017, 121, 14019– 14026,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpcc.7b03409
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      37
      First-Principles and Molecular Dynamics on A-D(π)-A Type Sensitizers for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: Effects of Various Anchoring Groups on Electronic Coupling and Dye Aggregation
      Wen, Yaping; Yang, Huiqing; Zheng, Danning; Sun, Kenan; Wang, Li; Zhang, Jinglai
      Journal of Physical Chemistry C (2017), 121 (26), 14019-14026CODEN: JPCCCK; ISSN:1932-7447. (American Chemical Society)
      The aggregation effect of five A-D(π)-A org. dyes, 1-5, with different anchoring groups is investigated by a combination of first-principles and mol. dynamics (MD). The dye with CSSH anchoring group (2) exhibits improved optoelectronic properties with the wider absorption range and larger absorption strength as compared with the other four dyes. More importantly, the stacking dimer of 2 has smaller or equal electronic coupling as compared with 1, indicating more efficient electron injection from dye to TiO2. Besides the isolated dyes, the monomer and two H-aggregation configurations of 1 and 2 are adsorbed onto the TiO2 anatase (101) surface to evaluate the injection time and variation of the band gap. The aggregation would be suppressed by choice of the suitable anchoring groups. Even if the aggregation is formed, it is not totally detrimental for the photovoltaic efficiency. The influence of aggregation is complicated and should be evaluated from many aspects.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC2sXhtVWhtLrP&md5=25a4364ec90decc08cb1ea4b3c855600
      open URL

      Roy, J. K.; Kar, S.; Leszczynski, J. Insight into the Optoelectronic Properties of Designed Solar Cells Efficient Tetrahydroquinoline Dye-Sensitizers on TiO2(101) Surface: First Principles Approach. Sci. Rep. 2018, 8, 10997  DOI: 10.1038/s41598-018-29368-9
      [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
      38
      Insight into the optoelectronic properties of designed solar cells efficient tetrahydroquinoline dye-sensitizers on TiO2(101) surface: first principles approach
      Roy Juganta K; Kar Supratik; Leszczynski Jerzy
      Scientific reports (2018), 8 (1), 10997 ISSN:.
      Seven 'lead' dye-sensitizers from Tetrahydroquinoline (THQ) family were proposed and designed based on the structural attributes via quantitative-structure property relationship (QSPR) modeling. They were screened rationally through different computational approaches to explore their potential applications as photosensitizers for dye-sensitized solar cells (DSSCs). Compelling photophysical properties such as electron injection driving force, electron injection time, and dye regeneration were studied for the isolated dyes under the DFT and TD-DFT frameworks. Index of spatial extent (S, D, and αq), the strength of charge transfer and separation along with the charge transfer process is explored. First principle approach including van der Waals density functional calculation of dye@TiO2 interface indicates that all of the designed dyes have optimal interfacial behavior. Bader charge analysis, partial density of state (PDOS), charge density and electrostatic potential difference calculation confirms that THQ7 and THQ9 are the most efficient dye-sensitizers. The other five designed dyes also possess the required properties to emerge as effective dye-sensitizers potentially better than those already utilized.
      >> More from SciFinder ®

      open URL

      Modeling the Photochrome-TiO2 Interface with Bethe-Salpeter and Time-Dependent Density Functional Theory Methods
      Escudero, Daniel; Duchemin, Ivan; Blase, Xavier; Jacquemin, Denis
      Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters (2017), 8 (5), 936-940CODEN: JPCLCD; ISSN:1948-7185. (American Chemical Society)
      Hybrid org.-inorg. semiconductor systems have important applications in both mol. electronics and photoresponsive materials. The characterizations of the interface and of the electronic excited-states of these hybrid systems remain a challenge for state-of-the-art computational methods, as the systems of interest are large. We present for the first time a many-body Green's function Bethe-Salpeter investigation of a series of photochromic mols. adsorbed onto TiO2 nanoclusters. On the basis of these studies, the performance of time-dependent d. functional theory (TD-DFT) calcns. is assessed. In addn., the photochromic properties of different hybrid systems are also evaluated. This work shows that qual. different conclusions can be reached with TD-DFT relying on various exchange-correlation functionals for such org.-inorg. interfaces and paves the way to more accurate simulation of many hybrid materials.

      DFT and TD-DFT investigations of organic dye with different π-spacer used for solar cell
      Li, Yuanchao; Lv, Yuguang; Liu, Yunpeng; Gao, Hongbing; Shi, Qi; Li, Yuanzuo
      Journal of Materials Science: Materials in Electronics (2017), 28 (13), 9642-9652CODEN: JSMEEV; ISSN:0957-4522. (Springer)
      The ground-state geometries and electronic properties of two D-π-A dyes (LEG4 and LEG4F) have been studied by using d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent d. functional theory. LEG4 and LEG4F have the same donor (triphenylamine) and acceptor (carboxylic acid) bridged by different π-spacer. We estd. the light harvesting efficiency, energy levels and electron d., electron accepting power, molar extinction coeff., electron injection free energy, chem. hardness and reorganization energy. The results demonstrate that LEG4F has higher HOMO energy and lower energy gap, which is benefit to electron transfer. For configuration of LEG4F, it was found that it has a widen absorption spectra and larger max. absorption strength, bigger light harvesting efficiency and improved electron injection ability in comparison with LEG4. The difference of photoelec. parameters for solar cell has been interpreted from the viewpoint of calcn., which is an important clue for understanding the relationship between structure and performance.

      Photoactive layer based on T-shaped benzimidazole dyes used for solar cell: from photoelectric properties to molecular design
      Xu, Beibei; Li, Yuanzuo; Song, Peng; Ma, Fengcai; Sun, Mengtao
      Scientific Reports (2017), 7 (), 45688CODEN: SRCEC3; ISSN:2045-2322. (Nature Publishing Group)
      Three benzimidazole-based org. dyes, possessing the same triphenylamine donors and cyanoacrylic acid acceptors with the bithiophene π-bridges combined in different nuclear positions of benzimidazole, were investigated in the utility of dye-sensitizer solar cells. The structure, MO and energy, absorption spectra and some important parameters (such as light harvesting efficiency (LHE), electron injection driving force, the electron injection time, chem. reactivity parameters, vertical dipole moment as well as interaction models of dye-I2) were obtained according to Newns-Anderson model and DFT calcn. The process and strength of charge transfer and sepn. were visualized with charge different d. and index of spatial extent (S, D and Δq). Current work paid attention to the new T-shaped dyes to reveal the relation between the structure and photoelec. performance. Furthermore, nine dyes (substitution of alkyl chains and π-bridges) have been designed and characterized to screen promising sensitizer candidates with excellent photo-electronic properties.

      He, L.-J.; Chen, J.; Bai, F.-Q.; Jia, R.; Wang, J.; Zhang, H.-X. Fine-tuning π-Spacer for High Efficiency Performance DSSC: A Theoretical Exploration with D-π-A Based Organic Dye. Dyes Pigm. 2017, 141, 251– 261,  DOI: 10.1016/j.dyepig.2017.02.023

      Fine-tuning π-spacer for high efficiency performance DSSC: A theoretical exploration with D-π-A based organic dye
      He, Ling-Jun; Chen, Jie; Bai, Fu-Quan; Jia, Ran; Wang, Jian; Zhang, Hong-Xing
      Dyes and Pigments (2017), 141 (), 251-261CODEN: DYPIDX; ISSN:0143-7208. (Elsevier Ltd.)
      Based on d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) approaches, a series of triphenylamine based org. dyes that modified by electron-withdrawing (EW) or electron-deficient (ED) substituent groups are investigated. The properties of all the isolated dyes, including frontier MO, intramol. charge transfer, absorption spectra, maximal photon generated current (Jph) and intermol. interaction between dye and I2 are investigated theor. to confirm which dyes can produce great performance for dye-sensitized solar cell (DSSC). Subsequently, the structures of dye combined with (TiO2)64 cluster are optimized by means of Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP) code. Then the interfacial interaction between the dye and semiconductor is further discussed to reveal the interfacial charge injection process by means of interfacial electron transfer code. The importance of fine-tuning π-spacer is also demonstrated by the d. of state (DOS) plot and photo-induced charge transfer dynamics. Compared with other dyes, TA-CN dye shows outstanding performance because of the strong coupling of the absorbed dye's orbitals with substrate orbitals and the fast as well as complete charge injection process. The purpose of the study is expected to provide a promising way to design possible candidate sensitizers for DSSC.

      Estrella, L. L.; Balanay, M. P.; Kim, D. H. The Effect of Donor Group Rigidification on the Electronic and Optical Properties of Arylamine-Based Metal-Free Dyes for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: A Computational Study. J. Phys. Chem. A 2016, 120, 5917– 5927,  DOI: 10.1021/acs.jpca.6b03271
      [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
      43
      The Effect of Donor Group Rigidification on the Electronic and Optical Properties of Arylamine-Based Metal-Free Dyes for Dye-Sensitized Solar Cells: A Computational Study
      Estrella, Liezel L.; Balanay, Mannix P.; Kim, Dong Hee
      Journal of Physical Chemistry A (2016), 120 (29), 5917-5927CODEN: JPCAFH; ISSN:1089-5639. (American Chemical Society)
      One of the most significant aspects in the development of dye-sensitized solar cells is the exploration and design of high-efficiency and low-cost dyes. This paper reports the theor. design of various triphenylamine analogs, wherein the central nitrogen moiety establishes an sp2-hybridization, which endows a significant participation in the charge-transfer properties. D. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT methodologies were utilized to investigate the geometry, electronic structure, photochem. properties, and electrochem. properties of these dyes. Different exchange-correlation functionals were initially evaluated to establish a proper methodol. for calcg. the excited-state energy of the ref. dye, known as DIA3. Consequently, TD-LC-ωPBE with a damping parameter of 0.175 Bohr-1 best correlates with the exptl. value. Four new dyes, namely, Dhk1, Dhk2, Dhk3, and Dhk4, were designed by modifying the rigidity of the donor moiety. According to the results, altering the type and position of binding in the donor group leads to distinct planarity of the dyes, which significantly affects their properties. The designed Dhk4 dye showed more red-shifted and broadened absorption spectra owing to the enhanced coplanarity between its donor and π-bridge moiety, which brings an advantage for its potential use as sensitizer for photovoltaic applications.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
      https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BC28XhtFekurvM&md5=b595f5711016065bec9ec22247142535

      Sun, C.; Li, Y.; Ma, F. An Experimental and Theoretical Investigation of the Electronic Structures and Photoelectrical Properties of Ethyl Red and Carminic Acid for DSSC Application. Materials 2016, 9, 813,  DOI: 10.3390/ma9100813
      [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
      44
      An experimental and theoretical investigation of the electronic structures and photoelectrical properties of ethyl red and carminic acid for DSSC application
      Sun, Chaofan; Li, Yuanzuo; Song, Peng; Ma, Fengcai
      Materials (2016), 9 (10), 813/1-813/22CODEN: MATEG9; ISSN:1996-1944. (MDPI AG)
      The photoelec. properties of two dyes-Ethyl Red and carminic acid-as sensitizers of dye-sensitized solar cells were investigated in expts. herein described. In order to reveal the reason for the difference between the photoelec. properties of the two dyes, the ground state and excited state properties of the dyes before and after adsorbed on TiO2 were calcd. via d. functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TDDFT). The key parameters including the light harvesting efficiency (LHE), the driving force of electron injection (ΔGinject) and dye regeneration (ΔGregen), the total dipole moment (μnormal), the conduction band of edge of the semiconductor (ΔECB), and the excited state lifetime (τ) were investigated, which are closely related to the short-circuit c.d. (Jsc) and open circuit voltage (Voc). It was found that the exptl. carminic acid has a larger Jsc and Voc, which are interpreted by a larger amt. of dye adsorbed on a TiO2 photoanode and a larger ΔGregen, excited state lifetime (τ), μnormal, and ΔECB. At the same time, chem. reactivity parameters illustrate that the lower chem. hardness (h) and higher electron accepting power (ω+) of carminic acid have an influence on the short-circuit c.d. Therefore, carminic acid shows excellent photoelec. conversion efficiency in comparison with Ethyl Red.
      >> More from SciFinder ®
